cheatsheetvideos.quote: Karla only needed to Study for 1 hour. She then went to the DMV and Passed her test
DMV Test Cheat Sheet: John Tells us How to Ace The Driver’s Test On your First Try

questions.question: When entering a street from a driveway, you:
questions.answerA: Must drive slowly to allow approaching vehicles and pedestrians time to get out of your way.
questions.answerB: Must honk your horn so approaching vehicles and pedestrians know to give you room.
questions.answerC: Must stop and proceed only when there are no pedestrians or vehicles approaching.
questions.answerD: Can disregard any pedestrians if there is no sidewalk.
questions.explanation: Always stop before entering the roadway from a driveway and yield to any approaching vehicles or crossing pedestrians. The stop should be made before crossing the sidewalk area. Failure to stop is unlawful.

questions.question: A red flashing traffic light has the same meaning as a:
questions.answerB: Stop sign.
questions.answerC: Yield sign.
questions.explanation: A red flashing traffic signal has the same meaning as a stop sign. When approaching a red flashing signal, come to a complete stop and proceed when it is safe to do so. A stop sign may sometimes also be posted where this signal is located.

questions.question: If a vehicle using high beams comes toward you, you should look toward ____ of the road.
questions.answerB: The center
questions.answerC: The right side
questions.explanation: If a vehicle approaching you is using its high beams and fails to dim them, you should glance toward the right side of the road. This will keep you from being blinded by the other vehicle’s headlights and will allow you to see well enough to stay on your course until the vehicle passes.

questions.question: At an intersection with a traffic light displaying a green arrow, you should:
questions.answerA: Wait to proceed until the light turns green.
questions.answerB: Stop, then turn in the direction indicated by the arrow.
questions.answerC: Turn in the direction indicated by the arrow when the intersection is clear.
questions.explanation: If you are in the proper lane, you must make the movement indicated by an arrow displayed on a traffic signal. A movement indicated by an arrow has the right-of-way and should not conflict with pedestrians or other vehicles. However, still be alert to other drivers and pedestrians who are wrongfully within the intersection.

questions.question: If you drive past your desired destination while in heavy traffic on a city street, you should:
questions.answerB: Back up to where you should have stopped.
questions.answerC: Signal and make a U-turn.
questions.explanation: If you realize you've passed your destination while driving in heavy traffic on a city street, you should circle around the block. Never make a U-turn where it may disrupt traffic.

questions.question: When approaching a school bus that is displaying flashing red lights, a driver should:
questions.answerA: Sound their horn and pass slowly.
questions.answerB: Stop, make sure it is safe to pass the bus, then proceed.
questions.answerC: Slow down and proceed with caution.
questions.answerD: Stop and remain stopped until the flashing lights extinguish.
questions.explanation: Drivers must come to a complete stop when approaching a school bus that has its red lights flashing and stop arm extended. Drivers should never try to pass a school bus that is loading or unloading children.

questions.question: If a transit vehicle is signaling to re-enter the main roadway following a stop, you must:
questions.answerA: Honk to let them know you’re there.
questions.answerB: Move to the left lane.
questions.answerC: Yield.
questions.explanation: You must yield to any transit vehicle that is signaling to pull back onto the main roadway after it has stopped to load or unload passengers. Change lanes, slow down, or stop to allow the bus safe re-entry into traffic.

questions.question: A single broken white line down the center of a two-lane road indicates:
questions.answerA: Lanes are moving in opposite directions and drivers are not permitted to pass.
questions.answerB: Lanes are moving in opposite directions and drivers are permitted to pass when it is safe to do so.
questions.answerC: Lanes are moving in the same direction and drivers are not permitted to pass.
questions.answerD: Lanes are moving in the same direction and drivers are permitted to pass when it is safe to do so.
questions.explanation: White lines are used to separate traffic moving in the same direction. Dashed lines indicate that drivers directly next to the line are permitted to pass when it is safe to do so.

questions.question: A solid white line on the right edge of the highway slants in to the left. That shows that:
questions.answerA: There is an intersection just ahead.
questions.answerB: You are approaching a construction area.
questions.answerC: You will be required to turn left just ahead.
questions.explanation: A solid line along the side of the road indicates where its edge is, marking the boundary between the travel lane and the shoulder. If the edge line angles toward the center of the road, this means that the road is narrower ahead.

questions.question: You are driving on a highway divided by two solid yellow lines. You may:
questions.answerA: Cross these lines only to make a left turn into or from an alley, private road, or driveway.
questions.answerB: Cross these lines to pass other vehicles, but only if there is no oncoming traffic.
questions.answerC: Cross these lines under no circumstances.
questions.answerD: Cross these lines only to make a U-turn.
questions.explanation: Double solid yellow lines are used to mark roadways where passing is prohibited from both directions. You may cross these lines only to make a left turn into or from an alley, private road, or driveway.

questions.question: The required amount of liability insurance coverage for property damage is a minimum of:
questions.explanation: The Mandatory Insurance Law requires either the vehicle owner or driver to carry liability insurance. The minimum required amount of liability insurance coverage is $25,000 for property damage.

questions.question: You must stop for a school bus:
questions.answerA: That is parked on the shoulder of the road with no one in it.
questions.answerB: When it approaches you, even if its lights are not flashing.
questions.answerC: If you are both driving on a two-lane highway and its red lights are flashing.
questions.answerD: Whenever the driver waves at you.
questions.explanation: You must stop when approaching a school bus that is displaying flashing red lights while stopped to pick up or drop off children. On a two-lane road, traffic moving in both directions must stop and remain stopped as long as the red lights near the top of the bus are flashing and/or the stop arm on the left side of the bus is extended.

questions.question: When the road is marked with a solid yellow line and a broken yellow line, with the broken line next to your lane, you may pass:
questions.answerB: If you are on an expressway.
questions.answerC: If traffic is clear.
questions.explanation: When there is a solid yellow line and a broken yellow line in the center of the road and the broken line is next to your lane, you may cross the lines to pass if there is no oncoming traffic.

questions.question: What should you do when an emergency vehicle is approaching while displaying flashing red or blue lights?
questions.answerA: See if you can reach your destination before the emergency vehicle catches up to you.
questions.answerB: Continue driving but try to stay out of its way.
questions.answerC: Pull over to the side of the road and come to a complete stop.
questions.answerD: Stop in the middle of an intersection.
questions.explanation: You must yield the right-of-way to all emergency vehicles using a siren, air horn, and/or flashing red, blue, or white lights. Where possible, you must pull over to the right edge of the road. If you are in an intersection, drive through the intersection before you pull over.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: You must stop for flaggers.
questions.answerC: The road ahead is closed to traffic.
questions.answerD: The highway ahead is undergoing maintenance.
questions.explanation: Construction and maintenance signs are orange-colored and are used to notify drivers of unusual or potentially dangerous conditions in or near work areas. This sign warns drivers that they are approaching a construction zone and that they should prepare to lower their speed and drive with extraordinary caution.

questions.question: Slower-moving traffic on a multilane highway should:
questions.answerB: Drive in any lane.
questions.answerC: Drive in the left lane.
questions.answerD: Drive in the lane with the least amount of traffic.
questions.explanation: If you are driving more slowly than surrounding traffic on a multilane road, use the right lane. The lefthand lane is intended for use by faster-moving traffic that is passing slower-moving traffic.

questions.question: Drivers who have consumed alcohol before getting behind the wheel:
questions.answerA: Are always aware of the risks they are taking.
questions.answerB: Do not have sufficient control over their bodies and minds or the vehicles being driven.
questions.answerC: Are better drivers because they are more careful than sober drivers.
questions.explanation: Alcohol is a depressant that negatively affects judgment, vision, concentration, understanding of reality, and reaction time. It is never safe to consume alcohol in any amount before getting behind the wheel of a car.

questions.question: The school zone speed limit is:
questions.answerB: 25 mph.
questions.answerC: 20 mph.
questions.explanation: The speed limit for school zones in Alaska is 20 mph. Always drive with caution where children are present.

questions.question: Statistics show that alcohol is:
questions.answerA: Involved in almost half of all traffic crashes that result in death.
questions.answerB: Rarely involved in any traffic crashes.
questions.answerC: The cause of all traffic crashes.
questions.answerD: Involved only in traffic crashes that do not result in death.
questions.explanation: Alcohol consumption is a significant factor in fatal motor vehicle crashes. In Alaska, almost 45 percent of all traffic deaths each year involve alcohol.

questions.question: To keep your vehicle from being struck from behind:
questions.answerA: Drive a little faster than surrounding traffic to widen the gap between you and the vehicle behind you.
questions.answerB: Brake harder than usual.
questions.answerC: Keep pace with surrounding traffic.
questions.answerD: Drive more slowly than surrounding traffic to maintain better control of your vehicle.
questions.explanation: It is a good idea to match the pace of surrounding traffic, within the legal speed limit. Driving with the flow of traffic keeps traffic moving and helps prevent rear-end collisions.

questions.question: This road sign indicates:
questions.answerA: The maximum safe speed for a residential area.
questions.answerB: The maximum safe speed for an expressway exit.
questions.answerC: The maximum safe speed for an expressway entrance.
questions.answerD: The maximum safe speed for a work zone.
questions.explanation: This advisory speed sign indicates the maximum safe speed for a highway exit (in this example, 30 mph).

questions.question: When driving on major highways:
questions.answerB: Keep your eyes moving.
questions.answerC: Be ready to react to road hazards.
questions.explanation: It is important to stay alert on highways and be ready to react to unexpected hazards. To avoid "highway hypnosis," you should avoid looking at any one thing for more than a few seconds.

questions.question: A red and white triangular sign at an intersection means:
questions.answerA: Slow down if an emergency vehicle is approaching.
questions.answerB: Look both ways as you cross the intersection.
questions.answerC: Always come to a full stop at the intersection.
questions.answerD: Slow down and be prepared to stop if necessary.
questions.explanation: A triangular red and white yield sign means that you must decrease speed as you approach an intersection and yield the right-of-way to any vehicles or pedestrians in the intersection. You must be prepared to stop if conditions require it.

questions.question: Which of the following lights indicates that you should slow down and proceed with caution at an intersection?
questions.answerB: A flashing red light
questions.answerC: A solid yellow light
questions.explanation: A flashing yellow traffic light at an intersection indicates that drivers must slow down, proceed with caution, and be prepared to stop.

questions.question: When you are in a line of traffic that is crossing a railroad track that has no signals or gates:
questions.answerA: You have the right-of-way and do not need to check for trains.
questions.answerB: You may pass slower drivers while crossing the track.
questions.answerC: You need to make sure there is space for your vehicle to get all the way across the tracks without stopping.
questions.explanation: If you are following another vehicle at a railroad crossing, check to make sure you have enough room to get all the way across before you drive onto the tracks. You should never try to pass another vehicle as you approach or cross a railroad crossing. Always check for trains before crossing any railroad tracks.

questions.question: When dealing with pedestrians, a driver must:
questions.answerA: Make sure the pedestrian is aware of their vehicle.
questions.answerB: Always yield the right-of-way, even if the pedestrian is in the wrong.
questions.answerC: Yield the right-of-way only when the pedestrian is legally entitled to it.
questions.answerD: Slow down and sound their horn near a crosswalk.
questions.explanation: You must do everything you can to prevent striking a pedestrian or another vehicle, regardless of the circumstances. It is the driver’s basic responsibility to be alert to pedestrians and to yield the right-of-way to all pedestrians, even if the pedestrian is crossing the street where they should not be.

questions.question: If your car breaks down on a highway, you should:
questions.answerA: Sit in your car and wait for help.
questions.answerB: Use your four-way flashers to warn other drivers.
questions.answerC: Sound your horn at passing motorists.
questions.answerD: Flash your headlights at oncoming traffic.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle breaks down on the highway, you should signal before carefully exiting the roadway and turning on your hazard flashers. Get as far off the road as possible and park in a location where other drivers can easily see you. Lift your hood to let other drivers know your vehicle is disabled.

questions.question: The consumption of alcohol while taking drugs can:
questions.answerA: Decrease the effects of the drugs and alcohol.
questions.answerB: Increase the effects of both the drugs and alcohol.
questions.answerC: Help cure your illness.
questions.explanation: The combination of alcohol and drugs, in some cases, can increase the effects of both the drugs and alcohol. It can be unsafe to drive after consuming either alcohol or drugs and is even more dangerous after combining them.

questions.question: An arrow painted on the pavement means:
questions.answerA: Drivers in the proper lane may make the movement indicated by the arrow, if they choose to do so.
questions.answerB: Drivers in the proper lane must make the movement indicated by the arrow, but only if traffic lights are not working.
questions.answerC: Drivers in the proper lane must always come to a complete stop before making the movement indicated by the arrow.
questions.answerD: Drivers in the proper lane must make the movement indicated by the arrow while following directions indicated by traffic signals.
questions.explanation: An arrow painted on the pavement within a traffic lane indicates that drivers in the lane must make the movement indicated by the arrow. Drivers should follow directions given by any traffic signs or signals before proceeding in the direction indicated by the arrow.

questions.question: What does this road sign mean?
questions.answerA: Slow down and prepare to stop if cars are approaching you.
questions.answerB: Come to a full stop and go when it is safe to do so.
questions.answerC: Proceed carefully through the intersection, not always stopping.
questions.answerD: Stop only for traffic on an intersecting road.
questions.explanation: A stop sign means that you must come to a full stop and yield the right-of-way to vehicles and pedestrians in or heading toward the intersection. Go again when it is safe.

questions.question: A stop sign is shaped like a(n):
questions.answerB: Square.
questions.answerC: Circle.
questions.explanation: An octagonal shape is used only for stop signs. All eight-sided signs tell drivers to come to a complete stop before proceeding.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerB: Winding road.
questions.answerC: Pedestrian crossing.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates a low ground railroad crossing. Where this sign is present, railroad tracks cross the road at a steep slope and the bottom of low vehicles may drag or get caught on the tracks.

questions.question: You are driving in the right lane of a multilane highway and want to move into the left lane. You should:
questions.answerA: Look in your rearview mirror for traffic behind you before changing lanes.
questions.answerB: Look over your left shoulder for traffic in your blind spot before changing lanes.
questions.answerC: Look in your side mirror for traffic and turn on your directional signal.
questions.explanation: Before changing lanes, you should always verify that there are no other vehicles in the lane you want to enter by checking your mirrors and looking over your shoulder in the direction you plan to move. You should signal every time you change lanes.

questions.question: If you experience a tire blowout:
questions.answerA: Take your foot of the gas.
questions.answerB: Do not immediately use your brakes.
questions.answerC: Gradually slow down and pull off the side of the road.
questions.explanation: If you experience a tire blowout, take your foot off the gas pedal and do not immediately apply the brakes. Gradually slow down before gently applying the brakes and pulling off the side of the road.

questions.question: Refusal to submit to chemical testing when requested by law enforcement:
questions.answerA: Will add 10 points against your license.
questions.answerB: Will result in revocation of your license.
questions.answerC: Is a criminal offense.
questions.explanation: Refusal to submit to chemical testing will result in two criminal charges: Driving Under the Influence (DUI) and Refusal. These charges may be treated separately in court. If you refuse to take a chemical test, the DMV is required to revoke your driving privileges and 10 points will be added to your license.

questions.question: When may you proceed through an intersection that has a stop sign but no stop line or crosswalk?
questions.answerA: After slowing down to verify that there is no cross traffic
questions.answerB: After coming to a complete stop and verifying that it is safe to proceed
questions.answerC: After you have stopped at least 20 feet prior to the intersection
questions.answerD: After slowing down to a speed of 10 mph
questions.explanation: Stop before the stop line or crosswalk at any intersection that is controlled by a stop sign. If there is a stop sign but no stop line or crosswalk, stop before entering the intersection and proceed when it is safe to do so.

questions.question: On each vehicle registered to the state, Alaska requires:
questions.answerA: One license plate on the back.
questions.answerB: Two license plates: one on the front and one on the back.
questions.answerC: No specified number of license plates.
questions.answerD: One license plate on the front.
questions.explanation:
A driver must have a single license plate with month and year tabs displayed
on rear of vehicle. If possible, a white light should illuminate the rear license plate so the numbers are visible for at least 50 feet.

questions.question: Stop lines are solid white lines painted across traffic lanes:
questions.answerB: Next to churches and schools.
questions.answerC: At intersections and pedestrian crosswalks.
questions.explanation: Stop lines are solid white lines painted across traffic lanes at intersections and pedestrian crosswalks. They indicate the exact location at which approaching drivers must stop.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: U-turns are permitted.
questions.answerC: Winding road ahead.
questions.explanation: A regulatory sign displaying a red circle with a red slash through the middle indicates that a specific action is prohibited. U-turns are not permitted where this sign is posted.

questions.question: A single dashed white line on a multilane road means:
questions.answerA: Lanes are moving in opposite directions.
questions.answerB: Passing is permitted into a lane directly next to the dashed white line.
questions.answerC: Passing is prohibited.
questions.explanation: Single dashed lines separate lanes of travel where changing lanes is not restricted. White lines separate lanes of traffic moving in opposite directions.

questions.question: When parking in an uphill direction on a roadway with a curb, your front wheels:
questions.answerB: Should turn away from the curb.
questions.answerC: Should turn toward the curb.
questions.answerD: May face in any direction, as long as you set the parking brake.
questions.explanation: When parking in an uphill direction on a roadway with a curb, turn your front wheels sharply away from the curb. When parking in an uphill direction on a roadway without a curb, turn your front wheels sharply toward the curb.

questions.question: If two drivers arrive at the same time to a four-way intersection controlled by stop signs:
questions.answerA: The driver on the right has the right-of-way.
questions.answerB: The driver on the left has the right-of-way.
questions.answerC: One driver may continue driving without stopping.
questions.answerD: One driver should honk to indicate that they are giving up the right-of-way.
questions.explanation: Yield the right-of-way to the driver on your right at a four-way intersection if you both arrive to the intersection at the same time. You may then proceed when it is safe to do so.

questions.question: How can you help prevent rear-end collisions?
questions.answerB: Before stopping, check your mirrors and blind spots for traffic.
questions.answerC: Release the gas pedal and let your vehicle slow before applying the brakes.
questions.explanation: Stopping suddenly can make it difficult for drivers behind you to avoid a rear-end collision. When stopping, release the accelerator to allow your vehicle to slow. Press the brake pedal by applying steady pressure, activating your brake lights and causing the vehicle to stop smoothly.

questions.question: When passing a large vehicle, the driver of a small vehicle must be prepared for:
questions.answerB: Excess air pollution.
questions.answerC: Wind gusts produced by the large vehicle.
questions.explanation: Large vehicles can cause wind gusts with a force great enough to cause direction changes in smaller vehicles. Drivers of small vehicles should be prepared to take proper corrective steering action when approaching or passing large vehicles that are moving at or near maximum speeds.

questions.question: This sign means that:
questions.answerA: A community service group is picking up trash along the highway ahead.
questions.answerB: Workers are on or very close to the road in the work zone ahead.
questions.answerC: Children are at play ahead.
questions.answerD: There is a pedestrian crosswalk ahead.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that workers may be on or very close to the roadway ahead, so you should take special care when traveling through the area.

questions.question: To avoid colliding with the car in front of you, you should:
questions.answerB: Watch for brake lights ahead.
questions.answerC: Use the four-second rule.
questions.explanation: To avoid rear-end collisions, it is helpful to look for break lights and other hazards in the traffic ahead of your vehicle. It is recommended that you maintain a following distance of four seconds when driving under ideal conditions.

questions.question: Blood alcohol content (BAC) depends on each of the following, except:
questions.answerB: How much you drink.
questions.answerC: How much time passes between drinks.
questions.explanation: Your blood alcohol content (BAC) depends on how much alcohol you drink, how much time passes between drinks, and your weight. It is not affected by the type of alcoholic beverages you drink, your level of physical fitness, or how well you can "hold your liquor."

questions.question: What might happen when alcohol is combined with another drug?
questions.answerA: The effects of the alcohol and the drug may both be increased.
questions.answerB: Nothing will happen.
questions.answerC: The effects of the alcohol and the drug may both be reduced.
questions.answerD: The effects of only the alcohol may be reduced.
questions.explanation: Consuming both alcohol and another drug may enhance the effects of both. For example, taking one drink when you are also using a cold remedy could affect you as if you have had several drinks.

questions.question: If involved in an accident, a driver should:
questions.answerA: Stop their vehicle at or near the scene.
questions.answerB: Not stand or walk in traffic lanes.
questions.answerC: Turn off the ignitions of wrecked vehicles.
questions.explanation: If you are involved in an accident, you must stop at or near the scene. Move your vehicle out of the way of traffic, if possible. Do not stand or walk in traffic lanes as you could be struck by another vehicle. Turn off the ignitions of wrecked vehicles.

questions.question: An approaching driver fails to dim their high beam headlights. Where should you look?
questions.answerA: At the wheels of the approaching vehicle.
questions.answerB: Toward the right side of the road.
questions.answerC: Toward the left side of the road.
questions.answerD: Straight down the middle of the road.
questions.explanation: If an approaching driver fails to dim their high beams, glance toward the right side of the road. This will keep you from being blinded by the other vehicle’s headlights and will allow you to see enough of the road to stay on course until the other vehicle has passed.

questions.question: If an aggressive driver cuts you off, you should:
questions.answerB: Stay calm and move out of the aggressive driver's way.
questions.answerC: Flash your vehicle's lights to let the aggressive driver know he is wrong.
questions.answerD: Use a driving action of your own to get back at the aggressive driver.
questions.explanation: If an aggressive driver cuts you off on the roadway, stay calm and get out of their way. Trying to get even with an aggressive driver risks escalating the situation and increasing the danger.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerB: Stop, if necessary.
questions.answerC: You must come to a complete stop.
questions.answerD: Drive with caution and be ready to stop.
questions.explanation: An eight-sided sign always means "stop." You must come to a complete stop and wait for any vehicles or pedestrians to clear the way before proceeding.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Divided highway ends.
questions.answerC: Two-way traffic.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually diamond-shaped with black markings on a yellow background. They alert drivers to upcoming hazards. This sign indicates that the divided highway is about to end.

questions.question: If you stop at a railroad crossing with more than one track:
questions.answerA: Wait to proceed until you have a clear view of all tracks.
questions.answerB: Stop on the first railroad track and watch for another train.
questions.answerC: Go through as soon as the train passes.
questions.answerD: Go through when one of the tracks is free.
questions.explanation: If you are stopped at a railroad crossing with more than one track, do not start moving as soon as a train passes. Wait until you have a clear view down all tracks before you start across. Even where there is only one track, do not start across immediately after a train passes; check again for another train that may be approaching.

questions.question: The driver's left arm and hand are extended upward. This hand signal means that the driver plans to:
questions.answerB: Turn right.
questions.answerC: Come to a stop.
questions.explanation: If a driver's left arm and hand are extended upward, they are indicating that they intend to turn right. Adjust your driving accordingly if following a driver who is using this hand signal.

questions.question: Parking lights may only be used:
questions.answerB: When visibility is poor.
questions.answerC: Within one hour of sunset or sunrise.
questions.answerD: When a vehicle is being driven under the speed limit.
questions.explanation: You must use parking lights when parking your vehicle. Only use parking lights when your vehicle is not in motion.

questions.question: You must stop at a railroad crossing when:
questions.answerA: Directed to do so by a flagger.
questions.answerB: It is controlled by a stop sign.
questions.answerC: Flashing red signals and gates are present and operating.
questions.explanation: You must stop at a railroad crossing when directed to do so by a flagger or stop sign. Stop when flashing red signals and gates are present and operating.

questions.question: When entering a highway from an entrance ramp, you should generally:
questions.answerA: Enter above the speed of traffic to get ahead.
questions.answerB: Enter slowly to avoid other vehicles.
questions.answerC: Stop first, then slowly enter traffic.
questions.answerD: Accelerate to the speed of traffic.
questions.explanation: Entrance ramps for highways often have acceleration lanes. When merging with traffic from an acceleration lane, you should put your signal on, look for an opening in traffic, accelerate up to the speed of traffic, and merge into an opening in traffic.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is true?
questions.answerA: Signal at least 100 feet before changing lanes to pass and ensure there is no oncoming traffic.
questions.answerB: Use your mirrors and look over your left shoulder to check your blind spot when passing to the left.
questions.answerC: When passing, wait until you can see both headlights of the passed car in your rearview mirror before returning to your original lane.
questions.explanation: When passing, you must always signal at least 100 feet in advance of your lane change. Always check behind you in your mirrors and look over your shoulder to check your blind spot. Wait until you can see both headlights of the passed car in your rearview mirror before returning to your original lane.

questions.question: If a crossing guard is directing traffic in a school zone, you must:
questions.answerA: Follow the directions given by the crossing guard.
questions.answerB: Copy what surrounding traffic is doing, despite the crossing guard's instructions.
questions.answerC: Assume the guard is not supposed to be directing traffic.
questions.answerD: Follow rules that would be in place if no children were present.
questions.explanation: Be prepared to reduce your speed and use caution when directed to do so by a sign, crossing guard, or law enforcement officer. Always drive with extra caution in a school zone.

questions.question: When riding in a vehicle, small children:
questions.answerA: May be safely held by a strong adult.
questions.answerB: Will be safe if they are standing on the floor in the back of the vehicle.
questions.answerC: Will not be hurt in an accident because they are small.
questions.answerD: Must never be allowed to ride while standing in the vehicle.
questions.explanation: Special child seats are available for children who are too small to wear regular safety belts. No person is strong enough to safely hold onto a child of any size during an accident or sudden stop. Never allow a child to ride in a vehicle unless they are properly fastened into a seat.

questions.question: You are driving on the roadway and hear a siren behind you. You should:
questions.answerB: Pull over to the right and stop.
questions.answerC: Speed up to get out of the way.
questions.explanation: When you hear the siren or see the flashing lights of an emergency vehicle coming from behind your vehicle, you must create a clear path for the emergency vehicle and stop. Reduce your speed and safely pull over to the side of the road. If the emergency vehicle is directly behind your vehicle when you are in heavy traffic, keep moving slowly until you can get out of its way.

questions.question: You are presumed to be driving under the influence if your blood alcohol concentration (BAC) is a minimum of:
questions.answerB: 0.1 percent.
questions.answerC: 0.05 percent.
questions.explanation: You will face legal consequences for driving under the influence if your blood alcohol concentration (BAC) is 0.08 percent or higher. Driving while under the influence of drugs or alcohol is a serious safety issue.

questions.question: If you’re going to turn left onto a one-way street, you should complete the turn into:
questions.answerB: The lane closest to your previous lane.
questions.answerC: Either lane.
questions.explanation: You should always turn from the lane that is closest to the direction you want to go. Turn into the lane closest to your previous lane.

questions.question: Which drugs may have an effect on your ability to drive?
questions.answerB: Prescription headache medication
questions.answerC: Illegal substances
questions.explanation: Alaska law forbids driving under the influence of any controlled substance, including narcotic and non-narcotic drugs. The penalties for driving under the influence of a controlled substance are the same as penalties for driving under the influence of alcohol. Always learn about the effects a new prescription may have on your driving before getting behind the wheel.

questions.question: This sign tells you that:
questions.answerA: No turns are allowed on this road.
questions.answerB: The road narrows ahead.
questions.answerC: There are a series of curves ahead.
questions.answerD: The road may be slippery when wet.
questions.explanation: This sign warns of an upcoming winding road with three or more curves.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Intersection ahead.
questions.answerC: Hiking trails ahead.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that a school crossing is ahead.

questions.question: Worn or bald tires:
questions.answerB: Are likely to hydroplane.
questions.answerC: Can increase your stopping distance.
questions.explanation: Worn or bald tires can increase your stopping distance and make turning more difficult. Tires without adequate tread also increase the risk of hydroplaning.

questions.question: Downward-facing triangular signs:
questions.answerB: Tell drivers to yield.
questions.answerC: Indicate construction zones.
questions.explanation: Downward-facing triangular signs usually indicate that drivers should yield. Once the road is clear of traffic or pedestrians and it is safe to do so, drivers may proceed.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Lane ends or roadway narrows ahead.
questions.answerC: Industrial area.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually diamond-shaped with black markings on a yellow background. They alert drivers to upcoming hazards. This sign warns drivers that the right lane is ending or that the road is narrowing ahead.

questions.question: You are approaching a flashing red traffic light. You should:
questions.answerB: Proceed only when it is safe to do so.
questions.answerC: Approach the light as if it were a stop sign.
questions.explanation: Treat a flashing red traffic signal the same as a stop sign. Come to a complete stop behind any crosswalk or stop line. Look in all directions for approaching traffic and pedestrians and proceed only when it is safe to do so.

questions.question: Drinking coffee after drinking alcohol:
questions.answerB: Cancels the effect of the alcohol.
questions.answerC: Has no effect on blood alcohol concentration.
questions.explanation: Drinking coffee will not reduce your blood alcohol concentration (BAC). While it may help you to stay awake, it cannot change your BAC or make you sober.

questions.question: A driver approaching a stopped school bus that is displaying flashing amber lights should always:
questions.answerA: Stop and remain stopped until the bus has passed.
questions.answerB: Slow down and prepare to stop.
questions.answerC: Sound their horn and pass slowly.
questions.explanation: A driver approaching a stopped school bus with its flashing amber lights activated must reduce their speed and prepare to stop. The driver must bring the vehicle to a complete stop when the school bus stops, activates its flashing red lights, and extends the stop signal.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Do not enter.
questions.answerC: Railroad crossing.
questions.explanation: This sign means that it is not safe for drivers to enter the indicated road or driveway from their current direction. If you come across one of these signs, you should immediately turn around and drive a different way.

questions.question: A flashing yellow traffic signal means:
questions.answerA: Slow down and proceed with caution.
questions.answerB: Continue ahead at your current speed.
questions.answerC: Stop.
questions.explanation: When encountering a flashing yellow traffic signal at an intersection, reduce your speed and exercise caution. Yield to pedestrians and vehicles already within the intersection.

questions.question: You are coming to an intersection and have a green light. Pedestrians are crossing against the red. You should:
questions.answerB: Speed up and pass in front of the pedestrians.
questions.answerC: Stop to let the pedestrians cross safely.
questions.answerD: Drive close to the pedestrians and frighten them so they’ll think twice before crossing against a red light.
questions.explanation: Yield to pedestrians and cars that may be caught in an intersection when you have a green light. Be careful around pedestrians under every circumstance.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerB: A steep grade is ahead.
questions.answerC: The overpass ahead has a low clearance.
questions.answerD: Two lanes of traffic moving in opposite directions are about to merge.
questions.explanation: This sign warns that the overpass ahead has a low clearance. Do not proceed if your vehicle is taller than the height indicated (in this case, 13 feet, 6 inches).

questions.question: What does a single dashed yellow line separating traffic mean?
questions.answerA: Drivers may pass if it is safe to do so.
questions.answerB: Both lanes travel in the same direction.
questions.answerC: Drivers may not pass.
questions.answerD: Drivers may pass, even if it could be dangerous.
questions.explanation: Yellow lines separate traffic moving in opposite directions. A single dashed yellow line in the center of a road indicates that vehicles traveling in both directions are permitted to pass. Drivers may only begin a pass if they will not interfere with any oncoming traffic.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerB: Steep grade ahead.
questions.answerC: Winding road.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that a steep downhill grade is ahead.

questions.question: Two solid white lines painted across a traffic lane show the boundaries of a crosswalk. As a driver, you should know that:
questions.answerA: Motor vehicles have the right-of-way over pedestrians in crosswalks.
questions.answerB: When pedestrians are in crosswalks, they should be given the right-of-way.
questions.answerC: No one has the right-of-way in a crosswalk.
questions.answerD: Pedestrians are responsible to stay out of the way of all traffic.
questions.explanation: Crosswalk lines show pedestrians where to safely cross a road or street. Crosswalks may be marked by horizontal lines, vertical lines, or a combination of the two. You must always stop for pedestrians who are in a crosswalk.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Low shoulder.
questions.answerC: No parking at any time.
questions.explanation: Regulation signs regulate traffic speed and movement, displaying rules which drivers must obey. This regulation sign indicates that drivers should keep right to avoid an upcoming potential driving hazard.

questions.question: What does alcohol do to your driving skills and judgement?
questions.answerA: It helps driving skills but harms your judgement.
questions.answerB: It harms both driving skills and judgement.
questions.answerC: It has no effect on either driving skills or judgement.
questions.answerD: It has no effect on judgement but it harms driving skills.
questions.explanation: Alcohol negatively affects many skills needed for safe driving, including your reaction time and ability to see clearly. It can also harm your judgment of speed and distance, lower your inhibitions, and make you more prone to taking chances.

questions.question: What is the minimum mandatory jail sentence for a first-time DUI conviction?
questions.answerB: 10 days
questions.answerC: 20 hours
questions.explanation: Driving Under the Influence (DUI) is a crime that carries a mandatory jail sentence. The minimum mandatory penalty for a DUI is three days in jail. Fees and fines will be charged in addition to mandatory jail time.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerB: No U-turns.
questions.answerC: No exit.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that right turns are prohibited.

questions.question: You must yield for emergency vehicles:
questions.answerB: When you see a flashing red or blue light or hear a siren.
questions.answerC: Only when other vehicles yield.
questions.explanation: You must yield the right-of-way to any emergency vehicle that is using its siren or flashing lights.

questions.question: When changing lanes you should not:
questions.answerA: Check your side and rearview mirrors.
questions.answerB: Give a turn signal to signal your intentions.
questions.answerC: Check for other drivers who may be moving into the same lane as you.
questions.answerD: Use your cell phone to contact the police to determine if the road ahead is clear.
questions.explanation: Before changing lanes, check your side and rearview mirrors for traffic approaching you from behind. Use your turn signal to let other drivers know you plan to change lanes. Check for other drivers who also may be moving into the same lane.

questions.question: When approaching a flashing yellow light, drivers should:
questions.answerB: Come to a complete stop.
questions.answerC: Turn on their headlights.
questions.answerD: Slow down and proceed with caution.
questions.explanation: A flashing yellow light warns of a hazard. Slow down and proceed with caution.

questions.question: If another car is in danger of hitting you, you should:
questions.answerB: Wave your arms.
questions.answerC: Use your emergency lights.
questions.explanation: Your horn should be used to warn other drivers or pedestrians in situations where they may not see you. For example, if you think another driver is about to hit you, you should sound your horn.

questions.question: Under Alaskan law, seat belts are required to be used:
questions.answerA: Only by children under the age of 16.
questions.answerB: Only by a person riding in the front seat of a vehicle.
questions.answerC: By everyone in a moving vehicle at all times.
questions.answerD: Only when traveling at speeds above 50 mph.
questions.explanation: Every person in a motor vehicle is required by law to use a safety belt, including the driver. The driver is responsible for the use of safety belts by all passengers under the age of 16.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: Parking spaces are reserved for people with disabled parking permits.
questions.answerB: A circular intersection is ahead.
questions.answerC: Traffic in the lane must turn in the direction of the arrow.
questions.answerD: Lanes are reserved for buses and vehicles with a driver and one or more passengers.
questions.explanation: This sign marks parking spaces that are reserved for people with disabled parking permits.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Slow down if an emergency vehicle is approaching.
questions.answerB: Look both ways as you cross the intersection.
questions.answerC: Always come to a full stop at the intersection.
questions.answerD: Slow down and be prepared to stop if necessary.
questions.explanation: Decrease your speed as you approach an intersection with a yield sign. Prepare to stop and yield the right-of-way to vehicles and pedestrians in the intersection or crossroad. You must come to a full stop at a yield sign if traffic conditions require it.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: You are about to enter a one-way street the wrong way.
questions.answerB: School crossing ahead.
questions.answerC: Do not drive in this lane.
questions.answerD: Traffic turning left on the green light must yield to oncoming traffic.
questions.explanation: This sign is used with a traffic signal to tell drivers that left-turning traffic does not have the right-of-way and must instead wait for oncoming traffic to clear.

questions.question: Your vehicle's stopping distance increases when stopping:
questions.answerA: On a wet or icy road.
questions.answerB: On paved highways.
questions.answerC: When driving at night.
questions.explanation: Stopping distances increase on wet or icy roads. Stopping distances also increase on road surfaces covered in loose gravel or stones.

questions.question: If you miss your exit on an interstate expressway:
questions.answerB: Get off at the next exit and come back to the exit you missed.
questions.answerC: Roll down your window and ask the driver next to you for help.
questions.explanation: If you miss your turn or exit, do not back up or try to turn around on the highway. Go to the next exit and safely turn around.

questions.question: The penalty for driving a vehicle without valid liability insurance is license suspension for a minimum of:
questions.answerB: 90 days.
questions.answerC: Two years.
questions.explanation: The Mandatory Insurance Law requires every vehicle to be covered by liability insurance. If you are involved in an accident while uninsured, or if you fail to provide proof of insurance within 15 days of the accident, your license will be suspended for a minimum of 90 days.

questions.question: You are involved in an accident and your vehicle is blocking traffic. You should:
questions.answerA: Move your vehicle off the traveled portion of the roadway, if possible.
questions.answerB: Not move your vehicle under any circumstances.
questions.answerC: Wait until the police arrive before moving your vehicle.
questions.explanation: After a minor collision, move your vehicle off the traveled portion of the roadway, if possible. Do not leave the scene of an accident without identifying yourself and rendering assistance.

questions.question: The road surface often becomes especially slippery during the first half hour of rain because:
questions.answerA: Dust and oil on the road have not yet washed away.
questions.answerB: Tires have not yet absorbed the water.
questions.answerC: Water tends to pool the most at the beginning of a rainfall.
questions.answerD: It rains hardest during that time.
questions.explanation: Road surfaces become especially slippery during the first half hour of rain because the dirt and oil on a road's surface will not have yet washed away. The combination of water with these materials forms a greasy film that tires cannot properly grasp.

questions.question: Motorcycles are entitled to:
questions.answerB: The same full lane width as other motor vehicles.
questions.answerC: Half the width of a lane.
questions.explanation: Lane usage for the motorcyclist is critical. Motorcycles are entitled to the same full lane width as all other vehicles.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerB: State park.
questions.answerC: Deer crossing.
questions.explanation: This sign warns that deer cross the roadway in the area. You should slow down, be alert, and be ready to stop.

questions.question: When driving on roads that may be slippery:
questions.answerA: Always drive at the maximum speed limit.
questions.answerB: Use cruise control to maintain a steady speed.
questions.answerC: Reduce your following distance.
questions.answerD: Do not make any sudden changes in speed or direction.
questions.explanation: You should avoid making any sudden changes in speed or direction when driving on a slippery surface. Reduce your speed on slippery roads and do not use cruise control.

questions.question: If you begin to feel tired while driving, the best thing to do is to:
questions.answerB: Open your window.
questions.answerC: Stop driving.
questions.explanation: Being fatigued while driving is similar in danger to driving under the influence of alcohol. If you begin to feel tired while driving, the best thing to do is to stop driving.

questions.question: When meeting a car with blinding headlights, you should:
questions.answerA: Use your bright lights until the other vehicle dims theirs.
questions.answerB: Flash your lights on and off to warn the other driver.
questions.answerC: Dim your lights and then speed up to pass quickly.
questions.answerD: Look toward the right side of the road.
questions.explanation: If a vehicle comes toward you with its high beams on, look away from the headlights and toward the right side of the road until the car has passed. This will keep you from being blinded.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Trucks are permitted on an upcoming narrow bridge.
questions.answerB: The bridge ahead is open to one-way traffic only.
questions.answerC: The bridge ahead is wide enough for only one car at a time.
questions.answerD: The bridge ahead may be too narrow to meet or pass a truck.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are used to warn drivers about upcoming hazardous conditions and are usually yellow with black markings. This sign warns drivers that an upcoming bridge may be too narrow to meet or pass a truck and that they should be careful.

questions.question: Increasing your vehicle’s speed:
questions.answerB: Decreases your field of vision.
questions.answerC: Makes it easier to see cross traffic.
questions.answerD: Has no effect on your field of vision.
questions.explanation: The faster you drive, the smaller your field of vision becomes. As your speed increases and your field of vision decreases, you must be extra alert to potential hazards.

questions.question: A steady green light at an intersection means that you:
questions.answerA: Must slow down and prepare to stop.
questions.answerB: Must stop and check for oncoming traffic before proceeding.
questions.answerC: May drive through the intersection if the road is clear.
questions.explanation: A steady green light means you may drive through the intersection if the road is clear. You may also turn right or left on a steady green light unless a sign prohibits the turn. When turning, you must yield to other vehicles and pedestrians within the intersection.

questions.question: On slippery roads, you should:
questions.answerB: Drive more quickly.
questions.answerC: Drive the speed limit, with caution.
questions.answerD: Not drive more quickly than 20 mph.
questions.explanation: You should slow down at the first sign of rain, snow, or sleet, all of which can create slippery road conditions. When conditions on the road are less than ideal, safety may require that you drive more slowly than the posted speed limit.

questions.question: If your turn signals fail, you should use ____ to indicate that you are turning.
questions.answerB: Your headlights
questions.answerC: Hand signals
questions.explanation: If your vehicle's turn signals do not work, you should use hand signals to indicate when you intend to change direction.

questions.question: Double solid yellow centerlines mean:
questions.answerB: Passing is not permitted.
questions.answerC: A residential district is ahead.
questions.explanation: Yellow lines separate lanes of traffic moving in opposite directions. Double solid yellow lines indicate that passing is prohibited from either direction.

questions.question: A telltale sign of a drunk driver is:
questions.answerB: They are driving more slowly than the normal traffic flow.
questions.answerC: They are making quick and sudden stops.
questions.explanation: Telltale signs of drunk driving include speeding, weaving, driving more slowly than the normal traffic flow, making jerking motions, and making quick and sudden stops.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: No parking.
questions.answerC: Right lane closed.
questions.explanation: Warning signs prepare drivers for upcoming road conditions and hazards and are usually yellow with black markings. This sign warns drivers that they are approaching a winding road and that they should adjust their speed accordingly.

questions.question: When approaching a traffic signal displaying a steady yellow arrow, drivers:
questions.answerA: Should merge into a lane in the direction of the arrow.
questions.answerB: Should slow to a stop, if it is safe to do so.
questions.answerC: May turn left after yielding to oncoming traffic and pedestrians.
questions.answerD: Have the right-of-way and may expect oncoming traffic to stop for them.
questions.explanation: A steady yellow arrow indicates that a red arrow is about to appear. Stop unless you are already within the intersection.

questions.question: Drowsy drivers:
questions.answerA: Should drink strong black coffee to stay awake.
questions.answerB: Can drive so poorly that they may appear to be drunk.
questions.answerC: Can stay alert by opening a window and turning up the radio.
questions.explanation: Drowsiness can make people drive so poorly that they appear to be drunk. Opening a window, turning on the radio, or drinking coffee is not enough to make a drowsy driver alert to roadway hazards.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is not true?
questions.answerA: Driving at high speeds can cause tire wear.
questions.answerB: Constantly driving at the same speed causes monotony and road hypnosis.
questions.answerC: Driving at high speeds results in poor gasoline mileage.
questions.answerD: You may not drive below the posted speed limit.
questions.explanation: Driving at high speeds results in tire wear and poor gasoline mileage. Vary your speed from time to time to prevent monotony and road hypnosis. You are not required to drive at the maximum speed limit. However, you should not drive so slowly that you interrupt the flow of traffic.

questions.question: Driving at night requires increased caution because:
questions.answerB: There is a larger volume of traffic at night.
questions.answerC: Drivers cannot see as well at night.
questions.answerD: Accidents occur more frequently at night.
questions.explanation: Because it is dark, drivers cannot see as well at night as they can during the day. From one half hour after sunset until one half hour before sunrise, or at any other time when persons or vehicles are not visible for 500 feet, drivers must use their headlights.

questions.question: A dashed yellow line on a roadway indicates:
questions.answerB: A safe passing area.
questions.answerC: A no passing zone.
questions.explanation: If you are driving next to a dashed line, passing over the line is permitted from your lane if the way is clear. Yellow lines indicate lanes of traffic moving in opposite directions.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerB: Lane reduction; the right lane ends soon.
questions.answerC: Highway entrance ramp ahead.
questions.answerD: Lane reduction; the left lane ends soon.
questions.explanation: This sign indicate that the right lane ends ahead.

questions.question: An approaching emergency vehicle is using its siren. You must:
questions.answerA: Slow down and drive with caution.
questions.answerB: Stop where you are.
questions.answerC: Drive to the nearest intersection and stop.
questions.answerD: Pull over to the side of the road and stop, clear of any intersection.
questions.explanation: Upon the approach of an emergency vehicle that is using its siren, traffic must yield the right-of-way by pulling to the side of the street and stopping. Drivers should remain in that position until the emergency vehicle has passed.

questions.question: To safely drive after drinking alcohol, you should:
questions.answerB: Drink black coffee or another caffeinated beverage.
questions.answerC: Take a cold shower.
questions.explanation: After drinking alcohol, there is nothing you can do to speed up the process of the alcohol leaving your body. Black coffee, fresh air, food, or a cold shower might wake you up, but they won’t sober you up. Only time will eliminate the effects of alcohol.

questions.question: Drivers must yield to a pedestrian:
questions.answerA: Even if the pedestrian crosses the street carelessly.
questions.answerB: Only when the pedestrian is in a crosswalk.
questions.answerC: Only if the pedestrian is on the same side of the road as the driver.
questions.answerD: If the pedestrian uses a hand signal to ask oncoming drivers to stop.
questions.explanation: Drivers must always yield to pedestrians in the street, even if they are crossing against a red light or are otherwise being careless.

questions.question: When approaching a railroad crossing, you should:
questions.answerB: Look for a train.
questions.answerC: Be ready to stop.
questions.explanation: When you see any signs indicating a nearby railroad crossing, you should slow down, look for a train, and be ready to stop. If the red warning lights are flashing or the gate is down, you must stop 15 to 50 feet before the railroad tracks. Do not try to go around the gate.

questions.question: If traffic signals at an intersection are not functioning due to a power outage:
questions.answerA: Park your vehicle as far off the road as possible and wait for power to be restored.
questions.answerB: Use hand signals to indicate your intentions to other drivers.
questions.answerC: Turn on your hazard lights and proceed through the intersection without stopping.
questions.answerD: Treat the intersection as a four-way stop.
questions.explanation: If a traffic light at an intersection is not functioning due to a power outage, yield to other drivers in the same manner as you would when approaching a four-way stop. When it is your turn, proceed through the intersection with caution.

questions.question: You must submit proof of insurance to the DMV within 15 days of a crash in which you were involved:
questions.answerB: If the crash results in personal injury, death, or property damage of at least $501.
questions.answerC: Only if property damage exceeds $1,000.
questions.answerD: Only if there is death or personal injury
questions.explanation: If you are involved in a crash resulting in bodily injury, death, or property damage of $501 or more, you must provide proof of insurance to the Division of Motor Vehicles within 15 days. Proof of insurance is required from all drivers involved in the crash, regardless of who was at fault.

questions.question: When turning left, drivers must yield the right-of-way to:
questions.answerA: Other drivers who are already in the intersection.
questions.answerB: Oncoming traffic.
questions.answerC: Pedestrians who are already in the intersection.
questions.explanation: When turning left, drivers must yield the right-of-way to oncoming traffic. Drivers must also always yield the right-of-way to pedestrians, bicyclists, and other drivers who are already in the intersection.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: You must travel at the speed indicated.
questions.answerB: The maximum legal speed on the roadway is 55 mph.
questions.answerC: You must travel through the intersection at the posted speed.
questions.explanation: This is a speed limit sign. It indicates the maximum legal speed that you may drive on the road where it is posted. At times of rain, snow, ice, or other less-than-ideal conditions, you may have to drive more slowly than the posted limit.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Flagger ahead.
questions.answerC: Lane ends.
questions.explanation: Warning signs prepare drivers for upcoming road conditions and hazards and are usually yellow with black markings. This sign alerts drivers to an upcoming intersection.

questions.question: A traffic light displaying a green arrow and a red light means that:
questions.answerA: You may only drive straight ahead.
questions.answerB: You may drive only in the direction of the green arrow.
questions.answerC: You must wait for a solid green light to proceed in any direction.
questions.answerD: Vehicles moving in any direction must stop.
questions.explanation: If a green arrow is shown with a red light, you can only drive in the direction of the arrow and only if the intersection is clear.

questions.question: A steady yellow light at an intersection means:
questions.answerB: Yield to other cars.
questions.answerC: Slow down and prepare to stop.
questions.explanation: A steady yellow light indicates that a steady red light will soon appear. If you are driving toward an intersection and a yellow light appears, slow down and prepare to stop. If you are already within the intersection or cannot stop safely before entering the intersection, continue through carefully.

questions.question: When is it illegal to drive below the speed limit?
questions.answerA: When driving slowly disrupts the normal flow of traffic
questions.answerB: When in heavy traffic in a construction zone
questions.answerC: Only when driving in rural areas.
questions.answerD: When driving under adverse weather conditions
questions.explanation: It is illegal to drive so slowly that you disrupt the normal flow of traffic. You may receive a citation for driving too slowly.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerB: Pedestrian crossing.
questions.answerC: Jogging trail.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates the presence of a pedestrian crossing. You should watch for people entering a crosswalk or crossing your path. Slow down and be prepared to stop.

questions.question: This sign shows one type of:
questions.answerB: Intersection.
questions.answerC: Lane change.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that a T intersection is ahead.

questions.question: An orange sign with black letters means:
questions.answerB: No turning.
questions.answerC: Roadwork is present.
questions.explanation: Signs in construction areas are usually diamond-shaped and orange with black lettering. Use extra caution when approaching or passing through a work zone.

questions.question: To stay safe while driving under poor weather conditions, you should:
questions.answerB: Not drive on bald tires.
questions.answerC: Slow down.
questions.explanation: Bald tires do not allow you full control of your vehicle while attempting to stop on a wet surface. Drive on tires with good tread at a safe distance from the car ahead. Decrease your speed any time conditions are less than ideal.

questions.question: You may drive around a railroad crossing gate that is being lowered:
questions.answerB: If the gate is malfunctioning.
questions.answerC: If you have plenty of time to cross before the gate is fully lowered.
questions.answerD: If there is a shoulder to the right of the gate.
questions.explanation: If gates are down at a railroad crossing, stay in place and do not try to cross the tracks until after the gates have been raised. It is against the law to drive around railroad crossing gates.

questions.question: As you enter an intersection, the traffic light turns yellow. You should:
questions.answerB: Accelerate.
questions.answerC: Stop as quickly as possible.
questions.explanation: When a traffic light turns yellow, approaching drivers must slow down and stop. If you are already within the intersection, or are so close to the intersection that you cannot stop safely, you may proceed through the intersection with extreme caution.

questions.question: To avoid collisions with vehicles in your blind spots, you should:
questions.answerA: Quickly turn your head to see if your blind spot is clear before changing lanes.
questions.answerB: Adjust your rearview mirrors every few minutes.
questions.answerC: Honk your horn right before turning or changing lanes.
questions.explanation: Before turning or changing lanes, turn your head and glance over your shoulder in the direction of your move to see if your blind spot is clear. Never rely on your mirrors alone.

questions.question: The driver's left arm and hand are extended downward. This hand signal means that the driver plans to:
questions.answerB: Turn right.
questions.answerC: Stop.
questions.explanation: If a driver's left arm and hand are extended downward, they are indicating that they intend to stop. Adjust your driving accordingly if following a driver who is using this hand signal.

questions.question: An orange triangle with red borders positioned on the rear of a vehicle means the vehicle is:
questions.answerB: Broken.
questions.answerC: A school bus.
questions.explanation: An orange, triangular sign with red borders indicates that a vehicle is a slow-moving vehicle. Drivers near a vehicle marked with this symbol should not expect the slow-moving vehicle to exceed a speed of 25 mph.

questions.question: You are driving in the left lane and want to move into the right lane. You should:
questions.answerA: Check your mirrors, signal, and look over your left shoulder for other vehicles before changing lanes.
questions.answerB: Check your mirrors, signal, and look over your right shoulder for other vehicles before changing lanes.
questions.answerC: Check your mirrors, signal, and look over both shoulders for other vehicles before changing lanes.
questions.answerD: Check your mirrors, signal, and change lanes.
questions.explanation: When changing lanes, you should check your vehicle's blind spots by looking over your shoulder in the direction that you want to move. Always check your mirrors and turn on your directional signal before beginning a lane change.

questions.question: Always signal when:
questions.answerB: Pulling into or out of a parking space.
questions.answerC: Pulling into traffic from an alley or parking area.
questions.explanation: Always use the proper turn signal when changing lanes, pulling into or out of a parking space, or pulling into traffic from an alley or parking area. Communicate with other drivers on the road to help prevent accidents.

questions.question: You may honk your horn when you:
questions.answerB: Are passing another car.
questions.answerC: Have lost control of your car.
questions.explanation: One situation where it is appropriate to use your horn is if you lose control of your vehicle. In this case, sound your horn to alert other drivers.

questions.question: If two vehicles approach an unmarked intersection at the same time:
questions.answerA: The driver on the right must yield to the driver on the left.
questions.answerB: Both drivers should accelerate.
questions.answerC: The driver on the left must yield to the driver on the right.
questions.answerD: One driver should insist on the right-of-way.
questions.explanation: If two vehicles arrive to an unmarked intersection at the same time, the driver on the left must yield the right-of-way to the driver on the right. No driver should assume that they will be given the right-of-way.

questions.question: If someone has consumed alcoholic drinks, what will help the person overcome the influence of those drinks?
questions.answerB: Hot coffee
questions.answerC: Fresh air
questions.explanation: Only the passage of time will allow a person to overcome the influence of alcohol.

questions.question: If someone is driving aggressively behind you, you should:
questions.answerA: Try to get out of the aggressive driver’s way.
questions.answerB: Stare at the driver as he or she is passing you.
questions.answerC: Speed up as he or she is passing you.
questions.explanation: If you encounter an aggressive driver, you should make every attempt to get out of their way. You should avoid making eye contact with a hostile driver. Challenging a hostile driver by speeding up may only make them angrier, thereby increasing their danger.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: No stopping.
questions.answerC: No U-turn.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that U-turns are prohibited.

questions.question: You are making a left turn from a two-way street onto a one-way street. When you have completed the turn, your car should be:
questions.answerA: In the right lane of the street.
questions.answerB: In the center of the street.
questions.answerC: In the left lane of the street.
questions.answerD: In the lane with the least traffic.
questions.explanation: If you are turning left from a two-way street onto a one-way street, you should complete the turn into the lane closest to the lane you have just left.

questions.question: Which of the following recommendations does not promote safe night driving?
questions.answerB: Be aware that tinted windows reduce visibility in the dark.
questions.answerC: Carry a flashlight in your vehicle.
questions.answerD: Look into the headlights of oncoming vehicles.
questions.explanation: If you look into the headlights of an oncoming vehicle, the pupil of your eye will contract. After the oncoming vehicle has passed, there will be an interval of time during which the pupil must readjust to the less intense light. During this recovery period, you are virtually driving blind.

questions.question: When you park uphill on a street with a curb:
questions.answerA: Keep the front wheel straight and set the parking brake.
questions.answerB: Turn the front wheels away from the curb.
questions.answerC: Turn the front wheels toward the curb.
questions.answerD: Turn the back wheels into the curb.
questions.explanation: When parking on an incline where there is a curb, you should turn your wheels sharply to the left, away from the curb. This way, if your brakes fail, your vehicle will not roll into traffic.

questions.question: A work zone:
questions.answerB: Is marked with black and white signs.
questions.answerC: Does not require a driver to slow down and pay extra attention.
questions.explanation: Work zones are often stationary, but they may also be present in the form of moving vehicles striping lines, mowing, or removing snow. Work zones are marked by orange signs with black lettering or symbols. Slow down and pay extra attention when approaching or driving through a work zone.

questions.question: Coming to a complete stop at an intersection, yielding to cross traffic/pedestrians, and then proceeding through the intersection when the way is clear corresponds with:
questions.answerB: A flashing yellow light.
questions.answerC: A solid green light.
questions.explanation: A flashing red traffic light means the same thing as a stop sign. You must come to a complete stop, yield to cross traffic and pedestrians, and then proceed when the way is clear.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Divided highway ahead.
questions.answerC: Two-way traffic.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually diamond-shaped with black markings on a yellow background. They alert drivers to upcoming hazards. This warning sign indicates that drivers are about to encounter a divided highway.

questions.question: A driver approaching a flashing red traffic signal must:
questions.answerB: Drive carefully without stopping.
questions.answerC: Merge to the right.
questions.explanation: A flashing red light means that you must stop, yield to traffic and pedestrians, and go only when it is safe. At a railroad crossing, a flashing red light indicates that a train is approaching. Yield to the train, and go only when the lights have stopped flashing and all other active warning devices deactivate.

questions.question: You must adjust your driving speed to accommodate for:
questions.answerB: Weather conditions.
questions.answerC: Other traffic.
questions.explanation: When driving conditions are less than ideal, a driver must decrease their driving speed. Conditions may become less than ideal due to the road surface, weather, time of day, road width, or traffic.

questions.question: Hand or mechanical turn signals must be given:
questions.answerB: Only when there is traffic to the rear of your vehicle.
questions.answerC: Only when there is other traffic in sight.
questions.explanation: A hand or mechanical turn signal must be displayed for a minimum of 100 feet before a vehicle turns or changes lanes. The signal should be displayed for a longer distance when the vehicle is traveling at a high speed.

questions.question: A person who drives much slower than the speed limit:
questions.answerB: Always has the right-of-way.
questions.answerC: Should not let following cars pass.
questions.answerD: May create a dangerous driving environment.
questions.explanation: Driving more slowly than the flow of traffic can be hazardous. If you are on a two-lane, two-way road and driving so slowly that traffic is backing up behind you, you are required to pull off the road and let the other vehicles pass. Only drive significantly under the speed limit when conditions require it.

questions.question: Dim your high beam headlights when you are within ____ of an oncoming vehicle.
questions.answerB: 400 feet
questions.answerC: 500 feet
questions.explanation: The glare of headlights from oncoming vehicles can cause the pupil of the eye to contract, restricting visibility. To protect other drivers when driving at night, change your headlights to their low beam setting within 500 feet of an oncoming vehicle.

questions.question: While backing, you should:
questions.answerB: Flash your lights.
questions.answerC: Open your door to see if it is safe to proceed.
questions.answerD: Turn your head and look through the rear window.
questions.explanation: When intending to back up, always check behind your vehicle before getting in. Children and small objects are difficult to see from the driver’s seat. While backing, turn your head so you can see through the rear window. Do not depend only on your mirrors or sensors.

questions.question: While driving on a two-lane road without bicycle lanes, you encounter a bicyclist traveling in the same direction. What is the safest way to pass the bicyclist?
questions.answerA: Slow down and wait until there is no traffic approaching, then pass the bicyclist while leaving him or her sufficient space.
questions.answerB: Continue driving straight. It is the bicyclist’s responsibility to get out of your way.
questions.answerC: Do not pass the bicyclist until you come to a traffic signal or stop sign.
questions.answerD: Honk at the bicyclist to let him or her know you are about to pass.
questions.explanation: You should pass a bicyclist the same way you would pass any other vehicle, but not so fast or close to them that you throw debris in their face or blow them around with the draft of air from your vehicle. Allow at least 3 feet of space between your side mirror and the bicyclist, or at least 5 feet on higher speed roads or when there is a group of bicyclists. Honking unnecessarily may startle riders and make them more likely to crash.

questions.question: Slow down, yield, and be prepared to stop for pedestrians:
questions.answerA: Only if a traffic light is yellow or red.
questions.answerB: As they are crossing or walking on the roadway.
questions.answerC: Only if they are in marked crosswalks.
questions.answerD: Only if they are crossing the roadway.
questions.explanation: Slow down, yield, and be prepared to stop when approaching pedestrians who are walking on or crossing the roadway. Always yield to pedestrians on the roadway, even if they are not following right-of-way laws.

questions.question: A solid white line down the center of a two-lane road indicates:
questions.answerA: Lanes are moving in opposite directions and drivers are not permitted to pass.
questions.answerB: Lanes are moving in opposite directions and drivers are permitted to pass when it is safe to do so.
questions.answerC: Lanes are moving in the same direction and drivers are not permitted to pass.
questions.answerD: Lanes are moving in the same direction and drivers are permitted to pass when it is safe to do so.
questions.explanation: White lines are used to separate traffic moving in the same direction. Solid lines indicate that drivers are not permitted to pass.

questions.question: In a vehicle not equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), you should pump your brakes to slow down because:
questions.answerA: It keeps air out of the brake line.
questions.answerB: It prevents skids.
questions.answerC: It prevents tires from going bald.
questions.explanation: Pump brakes lightly to slow down or stop on a slippery surface. If your vehicle is equipped with ABS, check your vehicle manual for instructions on use.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Crossroad ahead.
questions.answerC: No right turn.
questions.explanation: Warning signs prepare drivers for upcoming road conditions and hazards and are usually yellow with black markings. This sign warns drivers about an upcoming steep hill. They should adjust their speed accordingly to avoid brake damage or collision.

questions.question: It is illegal to park within ____ of a fire hydrant.
questions.answerB: 15 feet
questions.answerC: 30 feet
questions.explanation: It is illegal to park within 15 feet of a fire hydrant.

questions.question: What does an orange-colored sign indicate?
questions.answerA: The start of a no passing zone.
questions.answerB: A railroad crossing is ahead.
questions.answerC: A school zone is ahead.
questions.explanation: Construction, maintenance, and emergency operations signs are generally orange with black symbols.

questions.question: An octagonal sign is always a:
questions.answerB: Stop sign.
questions.answerC: Hospital sign.
questions.explanation: Octagonal signs are always stop signs. Come to a complete stop when approaching a red, eight-sided sign.

questions.question: Compared to driving during the day, driving at night is:
questions.answerB: No more or less dangerous.
questions.answerC: More dangerous.
questions.explanation: Driving at night is more dangerous than driving during the day for several reasons. It is harder to see in the dark, you may be temporarily blinded by the glare from other vehicles' lights, and there are likely to be more drivers on the road who are tired or under the influence.
