questions.question: Refusal to submit to chemical testing when requested by law enforcement:
questions.answerA: Will add 10 points against your license.
questions.answerB: Will result in revocation of your license.
questions.answerC: Is a criminal offense.
questions.explanation: Refusal to submit to chemical testing will result in two criminal charges: Driving Under the Influence (DUI) and Refusal. These charges may be treated separately in court. If you refuse to take a chemical test, the DMV is required to revoke your driving privileges and 10 points will be added to your license.

questions.question: If you are driving in another driver's blind spot, you should:
questions.answerA: Move forward or drop back so the other driver can see you.
questions.answerB: Keep a steady pace.
questions.answerC: Stay in the driver's blind spot.
questions.answerD: Honk to let them know you are there.
questions.explanation: Do not drive in someone else’s blind spot. Move forward or drop back so that the other driver can see you.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Flagger ahead.
questions.answerC: Two-way left turn.
questions.explanation: Regulation signs regulate traffic speed and movement, displaying rules which drivers must obey. This regulation sign means that left turns are prohibited.

questions.question: Highway markings:
questions.answerB: Are only found in construction zones.
questions.answerC: Provide information for drivers.
questions.answerD: Are usually red and blue in color.
questions.explanation: Highway markings provide information for drivers. Markings help drivers correctly position their vehicles on roadways, inform drivers of safe passing zones, and warn drivers about upcoming conditions.

questions.question: The “No zone” is:
questions.answerA: A term used to describe blind spots around a truck or bus.
questions.answerB: A special speed zone.
questions.answerC: A roadway with restrictions on vehicle stereo volume.
questions.answerD: The television show that replaced The Twilight Zone.
questions.explanation: A truck or bus has blind spots on each side, in the rear, and in the front. An automobile cannot be seen in these blind spots. These blind spots are referred to as the “No zone.”

questions.question: When a stop is required at an intersection and no markings appear to indicate a stop line or crosswalk, a driver:
questions.answerB: Is required to slow down to make sure crossing traffic is clear.
questions.answerC: Should stop only at a place where they can see at least 200 feet on either side, even if they have to enter the intersecting roadway.
questions.answerD: Should stop where they have a clear view of approaching traffic before they enter the intersecting roadway.
questions.explanation: If there is no stop line or crosswalk, you should stop at the point nearest to the intersecting roadway where you can get a view of approaching traffic. You should not enter the intersecting roadway to gain a better view.

questions.question: A driver entering interstate traffic from an entrance or acceleration ramp:
questions.answerA: Should yield to drivers already on the interstate.
questions.answerB: Has the right-of-way.
questions.answerC: May force their way into traffic.
questions.answerD: Can assume that other drivers will change lanes to make room.
questions.explanation: If you are on an entrance or acceleration ramp and are entering interstate traffic, you should yield to drivers already on the interstate highway. Merge safely into traffic when you are able to do so.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerB: The road ahead curves left, then right.
questions.answerC: The road ahead curves right, then left.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that the road ahead curves to the right and then to the left. You should slow down to be able to negotiate these curves safely.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Buggy warning.
questions.answerC: Limited parking.
questions.explanation: Warning signs prepare drivers for upcoming road conditions and hazards and are usually yellow with black markings. This sign tells drivers that there is an upcoming stop sign and that they should prepare to come to a complete stop before proceeding.

questions.question: Under ideal driving conditions, maintain a following distance of at least:
questions.answerB: 500 feet.
questions.answerC: Six seconds.
questions.explanation: When following another vehicle under ideal driving conditions, you should maintain a minimum four-second following distance. Increase this following distance any time conditions are less than ideal.

questions.question: To avoid colliding with the car in front of you, you should:
questions.answerB: Watch for brake lights ahead.
questions.answerC: Use the four-second rule.
questions.explanation: To avoid rear-end collisions, it is helpful to look for break lights and other hazards in the traffic ahead of your vehicle. It is recommended that you maintain a following distance of four seconds when driving under ideal conditions.

questions.question: When in a travel lane on the roadway:
questions.answerA: You may stop to drop off passengers.
questions.answerB: You may stop to look up an address.
questions.answerC: You may make a U-turn or back up if you get on the wrong entrance ramp of the freeway.
questions.answerD: Don’t stop for any reason. Keep moving until you can safely pull off the road.
questions.explanation: You should not stop in a travel lane for any reason. Instead, keep moving until you can safely pull off of the road. If you miss your turn or exit, do not back up. Go to the next turn or exit or where you can safely turn around.

questions.question: Traffic signs and pavement markings:
questions.answerB: Are merely suggestions.
questions.answerC: Must be followed only when there is other traffic.
questions.answerD: Must be followed only when a police officer is present.
questions.explanation: Traffic flow is controlled by pavement markings, traffic islands, signals, and signs. These devices inform drivers of conditions on the roadway and help guide drivers safely to their destinations. You must always obey traffic signs, signals, and pavement markings.

questions.question: Distracted driving is:
questions.answerB: Extremely risky behavior.
questions.answerC: Nothing to be concerned about.
questions.answerD: No less safe than driving under any other conditions.
questions.explanation: Distracted driving is extremely risky behavior that puts not only you and your passengers in danger, but also endangers pedestrians, bicyclists, and other motorists sharing the road. Focused attention on driving helps to prevent crashes.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerB: Pedestrian crossing ahead.
questions.answerC: Low ground railroad crossing.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that the overpass ahead has a low clearance. You should not proceed if your vehicle is taller than the height shown on the sign (in this case, 13 feet 6 inches).

questions.question: You are waiting to turn left at a multilane intersection and opposing traffic is blocking your view. You should:
questions.answerA: Accelerate rapidly when the first lane you need to cross is clear.
questions.answerB: Wait until you can see all the lanes you need to cross before going ahead with your turn.
questions.answerC: Wait for an oncoming driver to wave you across the intersection.
questions.answerD: Edge your car into each lane of opposing traffic as soon as it clears.
questions.explanation: You should never start a left turn until you can see that all the lanes you need to cross are clear and that you can safely make the turn.

questions.question: You must stop at an intersection when you see a:
questions.answerB: Steady yellow light.
questions.answerC: Yellow arrow.
questions.explanation: A flashing red traffic signal has the same meaning as a stop sign. At an intersection with a flashing red light, you must come to a complete stop, look both ways, and proceed only after the intersection is clear.

questions.question: When driving in fog, you should use your:
questions.answerB: High beam headlights.
questions.answerC: Parking lights.
questions.explanation: If you must drive in foggy conditions, you should use your low beam headlights, as well as your fog lights, if your vehicle has them. High beams direct their light upwards, where it can bounce off the fog and into your eyes, reducing visibility even more.

questions.question: Double solid yellow centerlines mean:
questions.answerB: Passing is not permitted.
questions.answerC: A residential district is ahead.
questions.explanation: Yellow lines separate lanes of traffic moving in opposite directions. Double solid yellow lines indicate that passing is prohibited from either direction.

questions.question: If your wheels drop off the pavement and onto the shoulder of the road, you should:
questions.answerA: Brake hard and turn sharply back onto the pavement.
questions.answerB: Stop your car on the edge of the road.
questions.answerC: Slow down and very carefully turn back onto the pavement.
questions.answerD: Maintain your speed and turn sharply back onto the pavement.
questions.explanation: If your wheels drop off the pavement and onto a low shoulder, you should reduce your speed without braking and very carefully turn back onto the pavement. Be aware of any nearby traffic when re-entering the road.

questions.question: The sign with this shape and color is a ____ sign.
questions.answerB: Wrong way
questions.answerC: Railroad crossing
questions.explanation: Pennant-shaped warning signs like this are only used to indicate a no passing zone.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Highway changes ahead and to the right.
questions.answerB: Hiking trails ahead and to the right.
questions.answerC: Hotel ahead and to the right.
questions.answerD: Hospital ahead and to the right.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that hospital emergency services are located to the right.

questions.question: Increase your following distance when:
questions.answerA: Driving behind a large vehicle that blocks your vision.
questions.answerB: Exiting an expressway.
questions.answerC: Following a motorcycle.
questions.explanation: You should increase your following distance when you are behind a large vehicle that blocks your vision, when driving in bad weather or heavy traffic, when exiting an expressway, when behind a motorcycle or bicycle, and if someone is tailgating you.

questions.question: Don’t follow other cars too closely because:
questions.answerA: You may not see the road between the cars.
questions.answerB: You may not have time to stop if the vehicle in front of you slows or stops suddenly.
questions.answerC: You may not see the vehicle's turn signals.
questions.answerD: You may not see the other vehicle’s brake lights.
questions.explanation: If you follow too closely and the vehicle in front of you slows or stops suddenly, you may not have enough time to avoid a collision.

questions.question: When getting ready to change lanes, you should:
questions.answerB: Check your rearview mirror.
questions.answerC: Quickly turn your head to check for other vehicles.
questions.explanation: Before changing lanes, check your side and rearview mirrors for traffic approaching you from behind. Just before you begin moving into the other lane, quickly glance over your shoulder and check for any vehicles that may be in your blind spot.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: You must drive slowly and sound your horn.
questions.answerB: A bus stop is ahead.
questions.answerC: You are entering a school's parking lot.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are used to warn drivers about upcoming hazardous conditions and are usually yellow with black markings. This sign tells drivers that they are approaching a school zone and that they should slow down and watch for children.

questions.question: Seat belts are most effective when they are worn by:
questions.answerB: Passengers when they are on a long drive.
questions.answerC: All occupants of a car being driven on an expressway.
questions.answerD: All occupants of a car every time the car is driven.
questions.explanation: When you drive, make sure each person in your vehicle wears a seat belt. In the event of a crash, a person without a seat belt becomes a flying object and a danger to each person in the vehicle.

questions.question: Drivers may not pass from either side of a ____ centerline.
questions.answerB: Single broken yellow
questions.answerC: Double solid yellow
questions.explanation: A double solid yellow line down the center of a two-way road means that it is prohibited for traffic from either direction to cross the center to pass.

questions.question: You are approaching a flashing red traffic light. You should:
questions.answerB: Proceed only when it is safe to do so.
questions.answerC: Approach the light as if it were a stop sign.
questions.explanation: Treat a flashing red traffic signal the same as a stop sign. Come to a complete stop behind any crosswalk or stop line. Look in all directions for approaching traffic and pedestrians and proceed only when it is safe to do so.

questions.question: A license may be suspended for:
questions.answerA: Driving in violation of license restrictions.
questions.answerB: Repeated violations of motor vehicle laws.
questions.answerC: Operating an uninsured vehicle.
questions.explanation: Violating motor vehicle laws and accumulating points against your driving record may result in the suspension or revocation of your driving privileges.

questions.question: A driver approaching a stopped school bus that is displaying flashing amber lights should always:
questions.answerA: Stop and remain stopped until the bus has passed.
questions.answerB: Slow down and prepare to stop.
questions.answerC: Sound their horn and pass slowly.
questions.explanation: A driver approaching a stopped school bus with its flashing amber lights activated must reduce their speed and prepare to stop. The driver must bring the vehicle to a complete stop when the school bus stops, activates its flashing red lights, and extends the stop signal.

questions.question: Your tire blows out while you are driving. You should:
questions.answerB: Hold your steering wheel tightly and slow to a stop.
questions.answerC: Keep driving normally.
questions.answerD: Turn on your emergency flashers and continue driving.
questions.explanation: If you experience a tire blowout, do not immediately apply the brakes. Grip the steering wheel firmly and steer to remain in your traffic lane. Reduce your speed gradually by releasing the accelerator and staying off the brakes. Once you are moving very slowly, apply the brakes lightly and pull off the road into a safe area.

questions.question: What does a traffic signal displaying a solid red arrow mean?
questions.answerA: Stop and proceed when it is safe to do so.
questions.answerB: Stop and do not turn in the direction indicated by the arrow until the arrow turns green.
questions.answerC: Turn slowly in the direction indicated by the arrow.
questions.explanation: Do not turn in the direction indicated by a solid red arrow. Come to a complete stop before entering the intersection. Do not proceed with the turn until the arrow changes to green or flashing yellow.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: One-way.
questions.answerC: Cattle crossing.
questions.explanation: Regulation signs regulate traffic speed and movement, displaying rules which drivers must obey. This regulation sign indicates that drivers turning left at a green light must yield to oncoming traffic and may complete the turn when it is safe to do so.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: School crossing.
questions.answerC: Pedestrian crossing.
questions.answerD: Construction workers on or near the roadway.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually diamond-shaped with black markings on a yellow background. They alert drivers to upcoming hazards. This sign indicates that there may be pedestrians crossing the road ahead.

questions.question: At a light rail intersection, always:
questions.answerA: Look both ways before crossing tracks.
questions.answerB: Pay attention and obey all traffic signals.
questions.answerC: Share the road with pedestrians and bicyclists.
questions.explanation: You should never drive around lowered crossing gates. Always look both ways before turning across train tracks and always obey signs and traffic signals. Trains share the road with motor vehicles and bicyclists.

questions.question: When backing up your vehicle, you should:
questions.answerA: Turn your head and body to the right to look out the rear window.
questions.answerB: Use only your rearview mirror to look for obstacles to the rear of your vehicle.
questions.answerC: Honk your horn so pedestrians and other vehicles know what you are doing.
questions.explanation: When backing, don’t depend on your mirrors. Instead, with your left hand at the top of the steering wheel, turn your head and body to the right and look out the rear window.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Fines double in a work zone.
questions.answerC: No left turn.
questions.explanation: Warning signs prepare drivers for upcoming road conditions and hazards and are usually yellow with black markings. This sign tells drivers that they are approaching an area with low clearance.

questions.question: To help relieve fatigue on a long trip, it is a good idea to:
questions.answerA: Stop and rest every two hours.
questions.answerB: Do arm exercises every hour.
questions.answerC: Drive with one eye open at a time.
questions.answerD: Change feet on the gas pedal.
questions.explanation: To avoid becoming fatigued while taking a long trip, stop every two hours for a short break. If you become drowsy, pull off the road and park in a safe place to take a nap, or find a room to stay for the night.

questions.question: When parking in an uphill direction on a roadway with a curb, your front wheels:
questions.answerB: Should turn away from the curb.
questions.answerC: Should turn toward the curb.
questions.answerD: May face in any direction, as long as you set the parking brake.
questions.explanation: When parking in an uphill direction on a roadway with a curb, turn your front wheels sharply away from the curb. When parking in an uphill direction on a roadway without a curb, turn your front wheels sharply toward the curb.

questions.question: What may help drivers conserve gasoline?
questions.answerA: Sitting in their driveways with their cars running.
questions.answerB: Accelerating quickly.
questions.answerC: Slowing down gradually.
questions.explanation: Every time you have to stop quickly, it takes time and fuel to accelerate and get your vehicle back up to the speed of traffic. Drivers who look far ahead of their vehicles can slow down gradually or change lanes to avoid unnecessary braking, leading to better gas mileage.

questions.question: If an officer is directing traffic at a working traffic light, drivers should:
questions.answerA: Follow the directions indicated by the traffic light.
questions.answerB: Follow the directions given by the officer.
questions.answerC: Honk at the officer.
questions.answerD: Check to see what the cars next to them are doing.
questions.explanation: Traffic signals are placed at intersections to keep traffic moving and to help prevent crashes. Drivers, pedestrians, and cyclists must obey these signals, except in instances when an officer is directing traffic.

questions.question: When approaching a steady green traffic light, drivers should:
questions.answerA: Continue driving, unless there are vehicles or pedestrians already in the intersection.
questions.answerB: Stop if a police officer is nearby.
questions.answerC: Treat the intersection like a four-way stop.
questions.answerD: Come to a complete stop before proceeding.
questions.explanation: When approaching an intersection with a steady green traffic light, yield to pedestrians in the crosswalk and vehicles still in the intersection. You may continue driving, but should approach the intersection at a speed that will allow you to slow down and stop if the light changes before you get there.

questions.question: Slower-moving traffic on a multilane highway should:
questions.answerB: Drive in any lane.
questions.answerC: Drive in the left lane.
questions.answerD: Drive in the lane with the least amount of traffic.
questions.explanation: If you are driving more slowly than surrounding traffic on a multilane road, use the right lane. The lefthand lane is intended for use by faster-moving traffic that is passing slower-moving traffic.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Roadwork ahead.
questions.answerC: Merging traffic.
questions.explanation: Warning signs prepare drivers for upcoming road conditions and hazards and are usually yellow with black markings. This sign alerts drivers to an upcoming curve in the road.

questions.question: When merging onto a freeway, it is usually best to:
questions.answerA: Proceed slowly while waiting for an opening.
questions.answerB: Accelerate to a speed that is faster than the speed of traffic.
questions.answerC: Turn on your hazard lights until safely on the freeway.
questions.answerD: Accelerate to the speed of freeway traffic.
questions.explanation: When entering a freeway, use the on-ramp to accelerate to the speed of freeway traffic so you can blend in smoothly and safely. Entering traffic must yield to traffic already on the freeway.

questions.question: You must pull over to the edge of the road and allow an emergency vehicle to pass:
questions.answerB: Only if it is following you.
questions.answerC: Only if it is approaching you from the opposite direction.
questions.explanation: You must pull over to the right edge of the road and stop for an emergency vehicle with flashing lights, regardless of whether it is approaching you from behind or from the opposite direction.

questions.question: What is the minimum mandatory jail sentence for a first-time DUI conviction?
questions.answerB: 10 days
questions.answerC: 20 hours
questions.explanation: Driving Under the Influence (DUI) is a crime that carries a mandatory jail sentence. The minimum mandatory penalty for a DUI is three days in jail. Fees and fines will be charged in addition to mandatory jail time.

questions.question: Your license will be suspended if you accumulate ____ points in a period of 12 months.
questions.answerB: 10 or more
questions.answerC: 15 or more
questions.explanation: Points are added to your driving record when you are convicted of a traffic violation. Accumulating 12 or more points in a 12-month period, or 18 points in a 24-month period, results in a mandatory suspension or revocation of driving privileges.

questions.question: The most effective safety restraints in a traffic crash are:
questions.answerA: Only a lap and shoulder belt.
questions.answerB: Only an airbag.
questions.answerC: Both a lap/shoulder belt and an airbag.
questions.explanation: Safety belts can double your chance of surviving a crash and more than double your chance of avoiding serious injury. Airbags, when used properly with safety belts, provide additional protection in a front-end crash. You should wear both shoulder and lap belts.

questions.question: When passing other vehicles:
questions.answerA: Check your mirrors and blind spots.
questions.answerB: Honk your horn at least three times.
questions.answerC: Re-enter your lane within 10 feet of the passed vehicle.
questions.answerD: There is no need to signal.
questions.explanation: Before passing another vehicle, check your mirrors and blind spots. Before changing lanes, activate the appropriate turn signal. Re-enter the lane when you can see the front of the passed vehicle in your rearview mirror.

questions.question: When a traffic signal light turns green, you should:
questions.answerB: Accelerate as quickly as possible.
questions.answerC: Back up slowly.
questions.answerD: Not move until another driver waves you on.
questions.explanation: A green light tells you that you can go through the intersection. However, you must first yield the right-of-way to traffic and pedestrians who are still in the intersection.

questions.question: The road surface often becomes especially slippery during the first half hour of rain because:
questions.answerA: Dust and oil on the road have not yet washed away.
questions.answerB: Tires have not yet absorbed the water.
questions.answerC: Water tends to pool the most at the beginning of a rainfall.
questions.answerD: It rains hardest during that time.
questions.explanation: Road surfaces become especially slippery during the first half hour of rain because the dirt and oil on a road's surface will not have yet washed away. The combination of water with these materials forms a greasy film that tires cannot properly grasp.

questions.question: If a green arrow turns into a solid green light, you:
questions.answerA: May still turn, but you must yield to oncoming traffic.
questions.answerB: May no longer turn and must proceed straight.
questions.answerC: Still have the right-of-way to turn.
questions.answerD: No longer have to turn in the direction that the arrow indicated.
questions.explanation: If a green arrow turns into a solid green light, you may still turn in the direction that the arrow was pointing but you must first yield to pedestrians and oncoming traffic.

questions.question: Pennant-shaped signs indicate:
questions.answerB: No passing zones.
questions.answerC: Speed limits.
questions.explanation: Pennant-shaped signs usually indicate no passing zones. Text will also be on the sign to confirm that it is a no passing zone.

questions.question: When you want to make a right turn, your car must be:
questions.answerA: Near the center of the street.
questions.answerB: Close to the left side of the street.
questions.answerC: Close to the right side of the street.
questions.answerD: Past the center of the intersection when you begin to turn.
questions.explanation: As you prepare to make a right turn, you should get as far to the right side of the road as possible. Do not cut across lanes of traffic to perform any turn.

questions.question: When driving near heavy trucks, other drivers and highway users must make allowances for:
questions.answerA: The increased stopping distance required by large vehicles.
questions.answerB: The decreased stopping distance required by large vehicles.
questions.answerC: The decreased noise of larger vehicles.
questions.answerD: The increased speed of larger vehicles.
questions.explanation: When driving near heavy trucks, other drivers and highway users must make allowances for the increased stopping distance required by the large vehicles. Drivers of smaller vehicles should remain in locations where they can be seen by the driver of the large vehicle and where their view of traffic is not blocked by the vehicle.

questions.question: When you see this sign, it means:
questions.answerA: There is an object on the roadway.
questions.answerB: Traffic is coming from the right.
questions.answerC: The road is curving sharply to the left.
questions.answerD: There is a merge point ahead.
questions.explanation: Chevron signs like this indicate that the road curves sharply in the direction indicated by the chevron (in this case, to the left). There may be several chevron signs placed throughout a curve.

questions.question: Which of the following is true regarding seat belts and child restraints in vehicles?
questions.answerA: You should never place an infant or small child in the front seat of a vehicle with airbags.
questions.answerB: An airbag can be dangerous to an infant or small child, even in a low-speed collision.
questions.answerC: You should always make sure all your passengers are using a seat belt or child restraint.
questions.explanation: Before you drive, always fasten your seat belt and make sure all your passengers are using seat belts or child restraints. Studies have shown that if you use seat belts, your chances of being hurt or killed in a traffic crash are greatly reduced. Children age 12 and under should always ride properly restrained in a rear seat. Never put a rear-facing infant restraint in the front seat of a vehicle with a front passenger airbag.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerB: No right turn.
questions.answerC: All traffic must go straight ahead.
questions.answerD: A road joins from the right.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that there is an intersection ahead. A road joins from the right.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Tow-away zone.
questions.answerC: Steep downgrade.
questions.explanation: Warning signs prepare drivers for upcoming road conditions and hazards and are usually yellow with black markings. This sign tells drivers to be cautious when driving under conditions that may cause the roadway to become wet and slippery.

questions.question: It is illegal to park within ____ of a fire hydrant.
questions.answerB: 15 feet
questions.answerC: 30 feet
questions.explanation: It is illegal to park within 15 feet of a fire hydrant.

questions.question: If worried, nervous, angry, or crying, a driver:
questions.answerA: Will drive no differently than they would if they were thinking more clearly.
questions.answerB: Can drive faster because they are more in touch with their senses.
questions.answerC: Should take the time to focus on driving before starting the engine.
questions.answerD: Should call a friend to vent while driving.
questions.explanation: You may not be able to drive well if you are worried, excited, crying, angry, or depressed. Emotions can distract you from your driving because your mind is focused on something else. Take time to calm down and get focused before driving.

questions.question: If you are stopped by a police officer, you should:
questions.answerA: Unbuckle your seat belt and lower your window.
questions.answerB: Get your paperwork ready before the officer reaches your car.
questions.answerC: Stay in your vehicle with your hands on the steering wheel and wait for the officer to approach you.
questions.answerD: Get out of your car and walk toward the patrol car.
questions.explanation: If you are stopped by the police, keep your hands on the wheel and ask any passengers to keep their hands in view as well. You should remain in the vehicle unless the police officer asks you to get out. Wait until the officer asks you to retrieve your driver license, registration, and insurance cards.

questions.question: At an intersection with a traffic light displaying a green arrow, you should:
questions.answerA: Wait to proceed until the light turns green.
questions.answerB: Stop, then turn in the direction indicated by the arrow.
questions.answerC: Turn in the direction indicated by the arrow when the intersection is clear.
questions.explanation: If you are in the proper lane, you must make the movement indicated by an arrow displayed on a traffic signal. A movement indicated by an arrow has the right-of-way and should not conflict with pedestrians or other vehicles. However, still be alert to other drivers and pedestrians who are wrongfully within the intersection.

questions.question: Smoking and preparing to smoke while driving:
questions.answerB: Help maintain driver alertness.
questions.answerC: Are distracting activities.
questions.explanation: Smoking while driving can create dangerous distractions by causing you to take your hands off the wheel and/or your eyes off the road.

questions.question: You are presumed to be driving under the influence if your blood alcohol concentration (BAC) is a minimum of:
questions.answerB: 0.1 percent.
questions.answerC: 0.05 percent.
questions.explanation: You will face legal consequences for driving under the influence if your blood alcohol concentration (BAC) is 0.08 percent or higher. Driving while under the influence of drugs or alcohol is a serious safety issue.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerB: You must bear either right or left.
questions.answerC: A four-way intersection is ahead.
questions.answerD: A road joins from the right.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that there is a Y intersection ahead. You must bear either to the right or to the left.

questions.question: Which drugs may have an effect on your ability to drive?
questions.answerB: Prescription headache medication
questions.answerC: Illegal substances
questions.explanation: Alaska law forbids driving under the influence of any controlled substance, including narcotic and non-narcotic drugs. The penalties for driving under the influence of a controlled substance are the same as penalties for driving under the influence of alcohol. Always learn about the effects a new prescription may have on your driving before getting behind the wheel.

questions.question: What do speed limit signs indicate?
questions.answerA: Potential driving speeds for the area
questions.answerB: The maximum or minimum speed that is legally allowed to be driven
questions.answerC: The speed drivers should drive in heavy traffic
questions.answerD: The speed drivers should drive under poor conditions
questions.explanation: Speed limit signs indicate the maximum or minimum safe speed that is allowed to be driven on a roadway. The maximum limits are for ideal conditions and you must reduce your speed when conditions require it.

questions.question: At a four-way stop:
questions.answerA: The driver to arrive first has the right-of-way.
questions.answerB: The driver to arrive last has the right-of-way.
questions.answerC: One driver should continue driving without stopping.
questions.answerD: One driver should wave the other drivers ahead.
questions.explanation: At four-way stops, traffic from all four directions must stop. The first vehicle to reach the intersection should move forward first. If two vehicles reach the intersection at the same time, the driver on the left yields to the driver on the right.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Trucks are entering the highway.
questions.answerC: Upcoming hill.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually diamond-shaped with black markings on a yellow background. They alert drivers to upcoming hazards. This sign indicates that drivers are approaching a steep hill and should prepare to adjust their speeds to continue to drive safely.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: The road ahead curves right. Slow down to the safe speed indicated.
questions.answerB: Divided highway begins. Slow down to the safe speed indicated.
questions.answerC: Merge. Slow down to the safe speed indicated.
questions.answerD: Winding road ahead. Slow down to the safe speed indicated.
questions.explanation: These signs indicate that the road curves to the right ahead and that drivers should slow down to the safe speed indicated (in this case, 35 mph).

questions.question: It is important to be alert to motorcycles because:
questions.answerA: They are more difficult to see than cars.
questions.answerB: They rarely use their headlights.
questions.answerC: Motorcyclists are less skilled drivers than other motorists.
questions.explanation: Motorcycles are smaller and harder to see than cars. Because of their size, they are easily hidden in a car’s blind spot. It may be difficult to judge your distance to a motorcycle and difficult to tell how fast a motorcycle is moving, so always be alert and extra cautious when near a motorcyclist.

questions.question: What is the only way to reduce your blood alcohol concentration (BAC)?
questions.answerB: Exercise.
questions.answerC: Allow your body time to get rid of the alcohol.
questions.explanation: The only method that effectively reduces your BAC is to not drink alcohol for a period of time. Coffee, exercise, and cold showers cannot reduce your BAC or change the effects of alcohol. They can help you remain awake, but they cannot change your BAC or make you sober.

questions.question: If your car starts to skid, turn your steering wheel:
questions.answerA: To keep the front wheels straight.
questions.answerB: In the direction you want the vehicle to go.
questions.answerC: In the opposite direction of the skid.
questions.answerD: In any direction. It doesn't matter.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle goes into a skid, you should turn the steering wheel in the direction you want the vehicle to go. As soon as the vehicle begins to straighten out, turn the steering wheel back the other way.

questions.question: When you hear a fire engine siren behind you, you must:
questions.answerA: Slow down until it passes you.
questions.answerB: Drive with your flashers on.
questions.answerC: Pull over to the side of the road and stop.
questions.answerD: Speed up and take the nearest exit.
questions.explanation: When you hear the siren of an emergency vehicle, you must pull over to the curb or side of the road and stop.

questions.question: Which of the following must you obey over the other three?
questions.answerB: A police officer
questions.answerC: A stop sign
questions.explanation: Directions given by traffic officers take precedence over signs, signals, and pavement markings. People authorized to direct traffic include police officers, fire police, highway work area flag persons, and school crossing persons.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is not true?
questions.answerA: Driving at high speeds can cause tire wear.
questions.answerB: Constantly driving at the same speed causes monotony and road hypnosis.
questions.answerC: Driving at high speeds results in poor gasoline mileage.
questions.answerD: You may not drive below the posted speed limit.
questions.explanation: Driving at high speeds results in tire wear and poor gasoline mileage. Vary your speed from time to time to prevent monotony and road hypnosis. You are not required to drive at the maximum speed limit. However, you should not drive so slowly that you interrupt the flow of traffic.

questions.question: You are driving when it begins to rain. You should:
questions.answerB: Drive at the maximum posted speed limit.
questions.answerC: Slow down.
questions.answerD: Drive closely behind the vehicle in front of you.
questions.explanation: When heavy rain reduces visibility, reduce your speed. Turn on your headlights so other drivers can see your vehicle. If the rain is so heavy that you are unable to see clearly, drive onto the shoulder and stop until the rain lets up.

questions.question: What should you do when you are going to enter a roadway from a private road?
questions.answerA: Blow your horn to warn cars you are entering the roadway.
questions.answerB: Stop with part of your car on the roadway to alert other drivers.
questions.answerC: Drive out fast to merge smoothly with the traffic.
questions.answerD: Yield the right-of-way to pedestrians and roadway traffic.
questions.explanation: When entering a roadway from a driveway or private road, you must yield the right-of-way to pedestrians and traffic on the roadway.

questions.question: The speed limit on most Alaskan roadways is:
questions.answerB: 60 mph.
questions.answerC: 50 mph.
questions.explanation: Business districts, alleys, school zones, and residential districts have their own specific speed limits. All other roadways in Alaska have a 55 mph maximum speed limit, unless otherwise posted.

questions.question: Road rage and aggressive driving may be reduced by:
questions.answerB: Obeying posted speed limits.
questions.answerC: Using proper turn signals.
questions.explanation: As an increasing number of drivers populate the roadways, road rage becomes more prevalent. To help prevent road rage, a driver should use proper turn signals, obey posted speed limits, and allow plenty of travel time.

questions.question: If you reach an intersection where you wish to turn but you are not in the proper lane, you should:
questions.answerA: Quickly cut across traffic to make your turn.
questions.answerB: Turn on your blinker and make the turn from your current lane.
questions.answerC: Drive to the next intersection and make your turn then.
questions.answerD: Safely change lanes then put your vehicle in reverse to go back to the intersection.
questions.explanation: Never make last-minute turns. If you reach an intersection where you wish to turn but you are not in the proper lane to make the turn, drive to the next intersection and then make the turn from the proper lane.

questions.question: You are driving on a narrow road when you meet an oncoming vehicle. You must:
questions.answerA: Pull completely off the road and stop.
questions.answerB: Allow the oncoming vehicle at least one-half of the main-traveled portion of the road.
questions.answerC: Demand the other vehicle pull over to make room.
questions.answerD: Turn on your high beam headlights to make sure the other vehicle sees you.
questions.explanation: On narrow roads, you must allow vehicles traveling in the opposite direction at least one-half of the main-traveled portion of the road. Both vehicles must have adequate space in order for the drivers to safely pass one another.

questions.question: Which of the following does not happen after drinking?
questions.answerA: Your reflexes and reaction time slow down.
questions.answerB: Your judgement of speed and distance is distorted.
questions.answerC: You are less alert.
questions.answerD: You calm down and can concentrate better.
questions.explanation: Alcohol reduces your reaction time, reduces your ability to see clearly, changes your judgment of speed and distances, reduces your ability to recover from the glare of headlights, and often reduces your inhibitions and makes you more likely to take risks.

questions.question: To check your blind spot before changing lanes:
questions.answerA: Look into the left side mirror.
questions.answerB: Look into the right side mirror.
questions.answerC: Look into the rearview mirror.
questions.answerD: Look over your shoulder in the direction you plan to move.
questions.explanation: To check your blind spot before changing lanes, you should look over your shoulder in the direction that you plan to move.

questions.question: You are involved in an accident. You should:
questions.answerB: Help the injured.
questions.answerC: Call the police.
questions.explanation: If involved in an accident, you should stop your vehicle immediately. If possible, move the vehicle out of the way of traffic. Call the nearest police agency and ask for an ambulance, if necessary. Do not move the injured unnecessarily, but attempt to stop severe bleeding with direct pressure. Wait for emergency vehicles to arrive.

questions.question: If you are driving so slowly that traffic is backing up behind you, you should:
questions.answerB: Pull off the right side of the road and let traffic pass.
questions.answerC: Not let the other cars pass your vehicle.
questions.explanation: Driving more slowly than the flow of traffic can be hazardous. If you are on a two-lane, two-way road and driving so slowly that traffic is backing up behind you, you are required to pull off the road and let the other vehicles pass. Only drive significantly under the speed limit when conditions require it.

questions.question: The school zone speed limit is:
questions.answerB: 25 mph.
questions.answerC: 20 mph.
questions.explanation: The speed limit for school zones in Alaska is 20 mph. Always drive with caution where children are present.

questions.question: This is a ____ sign.
questions.answerB: Wrong way
questions.answerC: Yield
questions.explanation: This triangular sign is a "Yield" sign. When you see this sign, you must slow down to check for traffic and yield the right-of-way to pedestrians and approaching cross traffic. Stop only if it is necessary to do so.

questions.question: What is a "No zone?"
questions.answerB: A one-way traffic area
questions.answerC: The blind spot of a large vehicle
questions.answerD: An area designated for motor vehicles
questions.explanation: "No zones" are the large blind spots around trucks and other large vehicles. Drivers of smaller vehicles should avoid lingering in "No zones."

questions.question: Night driving can be more difficult than driving during the day because:
questions.answerA: Cars overheat more quickly at night.
questions.answerB: Visibility is reduced in the dark.
questions.answerC: It is more likely to be raining at night.
questions.answerD: You are more likely to encounter a motorcycle at night.
questions.explanation: At night, your field of vision is reduced. To make sure you are able to react to hazards on the roadway, always use appropriate headlights. Drive slowly enough that you are able to stop within the distance that you can see ahead.

questions.question: Two solid yellow lines on the pavement mean:
questions.answerA: Passing is allowed for drivers from both directions.
questions.answerB: Passing is not allowed.
questions.answerC: Passing is allowed if you are at the top a hill.
questions.answerD: Passing is allowed during daylight only.
questions.explanation: Yellow lines tell you that the traffic on the other side of the lines is moving in the opposite direction. You should never cross two solid yellow lines to pass from either direction.

questions.question: When parallel parking between two cars, you should first:
questions.answerA: Turn your wheels to the left.
questions.answerB: Turn your wheels to the right.
questions.answerC: Pull up even with the car in front of your desired parking space.
questions.explanation: After finding a parking space, checking traffic, and signaling, you should stop parallel to the vehicle directly ahead of your desired parking space before turning your wheel to park.

questions.question: On long trips, you can prevent drowsiness by:
questions.answerB: Slowing down.
questions.answerC: Stopping at regular intervals for a rest.
questions.answerD: Moving your eyes from side to side as you drive.
questions.explanation: To prevent drowsiness on long trips, you should schedule regular stops. Give yourself time to rest and stretch, even if you are not feeling tired.

questions.question: When exiting a highway, you should slow down:
questions.answerA: On the main road, just before the exit lane.
questions.answerB: Once you see a toll booth.
questions.answerC: Once you have moved into the exit lane.
questions.answerD: When you first see the exit sign.
questions.explanation: When exiting a highway, you should get into the exit lane well in advance. Do not begin to slow down until after you have moved into the exit lane.

questions.question: To safely drive after drinking alcohol, you should:
questions.answerB: Drink black coffee or another caffeinated beverage.
questions.answerC: Take a cold shower.
questions.explanation: After drinking alcohol, there is nothing you can do to speed up the process of the alcohol leaving your body. Black coffee, fresh air, food, or a cold shower might wake you up, but they won’t sober you up. Only time will eliminate the effects of alcohol.

questions.question: When changing lanes on a multilane roadway, you should:
questions.answerA: Honk your horn to let drivers behind you know you might not be able to see them.
questions.answerB: Slow down to shrink your blind spot.
questions.answerC: Look in your mirrors before staring straight ahead.
questions.explanation: Before changing lanes on a multilane roadway, you should check your mirrors and blind spots. Check your blind spot by looking over your shoulder in the direction that you are moving.

questions.question: When the driver behind you wants to pass, you should:
questions.answerB: Go the same speed.
questions.answerC: Slow down to allow room in front of your vehicle for the other driver to complete the pass easily.
questions.explanation: When the driver behind you wants to pass, you should slow down so that there is enough room in front of your vehicle for the other driver to complete their pass. This will allow them to complete the passing maneuver in less time and more easily.

questions.question: To prepare for anything coming up on the road ahead, you should:
questions.answerA: Continually scan the entire road and all roadsides.
questions.answerB: Stare straight ahead at all times.
questions.answerC: Drive with your left foot resting lightly on the brake pedal.
questions.answerD: Maintain focus toward the middle of the road.
questions.explanation: Your ability to handle dangerous traffic situations depends largely on searching for and identifying problems before meeting them. Looking far ahead of your vehicle does not mean you should simply stare at the center of the road. You need to continually scan the entire road, including the sides of the road.

questions.question: An approaching emergency vehicle is using its siren. You must:
questions.answerA: Slow down and drive with caution.
questions.answerB: Stop where you are.
questions.answerC: Drive to the nearest intersection and stop.
questions.answerD: Pull over to the side of the road and stop, clear of any intersection.
questions.explanation: Upon the approach of an emergency vehicle that is using its siren, traffic must yield the right-of-way by pulling to the side of the street and stopping. Drivers should remain in that position until the emergency vehicle has passed.

questions.question: Which of the following recommendations does not promote safe night driving?
questions.answerB: Be aware that tinted windows reduce visibility in the dark.
questions.answerC: Carry a flashlight in your vehicle.
questions.answerD: Look into the headlights of oncoming vehicles.
questions.explanation: If you look into the headlights of an oncoming vehicle, the pupil of your eye will contract. After the oncoming vehicle has passed, there will be an interval of time during which the pupil must readjust to the less intense light. During this recovery period, you are virtually driving blind.

questions.question: A driver who fails to restrain passengers under the age of 16 in their moving vehicle may receive a fine of up to ____ per passenger.
questions.explanation: A driver can be fined up to $50 for each passenger under the age of 16 who is riding in their vehicle without proper safety restraints. The driver may also receive two demerit points on their license for this infraction.

questions.question: When approaching railroad tracks, you should:
questions.answerA: Look, listen, slow down, and be prepared to stop.
questions.answerB: Speed up to cross the tracks before the gate is lowered.
questions.answerC: Try to drive around a lowered gate.
questions.answerD: Not pay attention to how many tracks there are to cross.
questions.explanation: When approaching railroad tracks, you should look, listen, slow down, and be prepared to stop for trains or other vehicles that may be using the rails.

questions.question: What kinds of drugs can affect your driving ability?
questions.answerB: Marijuana
questions.answerC: Cold remedies
questions.explanation: Many kinds of drugs can impair your ability to drive. This includes illegal drugs and legal prescription or over-the-counter medications. It can be a criminal offense to drive while impaired by any drug.

questions.question: Your body gets rid of approximately:
questions.answerB: One alcoholic drink an hour.
questions.answerC: Two alcoholic drinks an hour.
questions.explanation: The average person’s body will process about one alcoholic drink in one hour. However, many factors play a part in determining how impaired a person will become when consuming alcohol, including the amount of alcohol consumed, how fast it is consumed, and a person’s body weight, food intake, and general health.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Work crew ahead.
questions.answerC: Side road.
questions.explanation: Warning signs prepare drivers for upcoming road conditions and hazards and are usually yellow with black markings. This sign warns drivers that there is an upcoming sharp turn and that they should lower their speed accordingly.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Divided highway ahead.
questions.answerC: Left turn signal.
questions.explanation: Regulation signs regulate traffic speed and movement, displaying rules which drivers must obey. This regulation sign indicates that parking is not permitted.

questions.question: When changing lanes, you should:
questions.answerB: Begin signaling as you move into the next lane.
questions.answerC: Signal at least 500 feet before your lane change when driving on residential streets.
questions.explanation: Other cars and motorcycles are often hidden in a vehicle’s blind spot, so be sure to glance over your shoulder before you begin a lane change. Begin signaling 100 feet before changing lanes or turning in a residential area. Signal five seconds in advance when changing lanes on a freeway.

questions.question: The act of turning your head and checking your blind spot before changing lanes, driving away from a curb, or merging your vehicle into traffic is:
questions.answerB: A good driving habit.
questions.answerC: Unnecessary.
questions.answerD: Not necessary if you use the rearview mirror.
questions.explanation: When changing lanes, it is important to check your blind spots. Do this by looking over your shoulder toward the next lane. Do not rely only on your mirrors.

questions.question: This sign is used to prevent:
questions.answerB: Entrance to road construction areas.
questions.answerC: Entrance to dead-end streets.
questions.answerD: Entrances from the wrong direction on one-way streets and expressway ramps.
questions.explanation: This sign warns that a road has one-way traffic and you must not enter from your current direction.

questions.question: You are approaching a railroad crossing that has no visible gates or flashing lights, but has a standard crossbuck. You should:
questions.answerA: Approach all tracks with extreme caution and cross only when you know that there is no train coming.
questions.answerB: Turn your radio down to hear if there may be an approaching train.
questions.answerC: Only continue once cleared to do so by a flagger, if applicable.
questions.explanation: You must approach all railroad crossings with extreme caution and cross only when you know that no train is coming from either direction. If there is a flagger at a crossing, you must obey all of their instructions.

questions.question: You must adjust your driving speed to accommodate for:
questions.answerB: Weather conditions.
questions.answerC: Other traffic.
questions.explanation: When driving conditions are less than ideal, a driver must decrease their driving speed. Conditions may become less than ideal due to the road surface, weather, time of day, road width, or traffic.

questions.question: In a vehicle not equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), you should pump your brakes to slow down because:
questions.answerA: It keeps air out of the brake line.
questions.answerB: It prevents skids.
questions.answerC: It prevents tires from going bald.
questions.explanation: Pump brakes lightly to slow down or stop on a slippery surface. If your vehicle is equipped with ABS, check your vehicle manual for instructions on use.

questions.question: A slow-moving vehicle emblem is:
questions.answerB: A circular green sign.
questions.answerC: A diamond-shaped yellow sign.
questions.explanation: The slow-moving vehicle symbol is a reflective orange triangle. Expect vehicles using this emblem to be driving at speeds of 25 mph or slower.

questions.question: This green arrow on a lane use control signal means:
questions.answerB: No traffic is allowed in this lane.
questions.answerC: You have the right-of-way.
questions.answerD: You must merge into this lane.
questions.explanation: A steady downward green arrow over a traffic lane means you may use the lane indicated.

questions.question: As you enter an intersection, the traffic light turns yellow. You should:
questions.answerB: Accelerate.
questions.answerC: Stop as quickly as possible.
questions.explanation: When a traffic light turns yellow, approaching drivers must slow down and stop. If you are already within the intersection, or are so close to the intersection that you cannot stop safely, you may proceed through the intersection with extreme caution.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: A one-way street begins.
questions.answerC: A one-way street ends.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that the road ahead becomes a divided highway. Keep to the right of the divider or median.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Side road.
questions.answerC: Two-way left turn.
questions.explanation: Eight-sided traffic signs warn drivers that they must stop and yield the appropriate right-of-way at an intersection. Drivers may proceed when it is safe to do so.

questions.question: What are the colors of signs that tell you the distance to the next exit on a highway?
questions.answerB: Black with white letters
questions.answerC: Red with white letters
questions.explanation: Signs providing information about destinations are green with white letters or symbols.

questions.question: A conviction of reckless driving will result in:
questions.answerA: A $50 fine and four points on your driving record.
questions.answerB: A warning for the first occurrence, and a $50 fine for a second.
questions.answerC: Suspension of your driving privileges.
questions.explanation: Reckless driving is a willful disregard for the safety of persons and property. Conviction will result in license revocation.

questions.question: Parking lights may only be used:
questions.answerB: When visibility is poor.
questions.answerC: Within one hour of sunset or sunrise.
questions.answerD: When a vehicle is being driven under the speed limit.
questions.explanation: You must use parking lights when parking your vehicle. Only use parking lights when your vehicle is not in motion.

questions.question: An orange sign with black letters means:
questions.answerB: No turning.
questions.answerC: Roadwork is present.
questions.explanation: Signs in construction areas are usually diamond-shaped and orange with black lettering. Use extra caution when approaching or passing through a work zone.

questions.question: You are coming to a railroad crossing where the crossing signals are flashing. You should:
questions.answerA: Stop and look for a train.
questions.answerB: Slow down and look for a train.
questions.answerC: Look for a train, then speed up.
questions.answerD: Do what the vehicle ahead of you does.
questions.explanation: When approaching a railroad crossing, you must stop your vehicle no closer than 15 feet from the nearest rail if an installed electric or mechanical signal is giving warning of an approaching train. Be aware of other warning signs that may indicate an oncoming train, including seeing a lowered crossing gate or hearing an oncoming train.

questions.question: When turning right from a two-way street onto another two-way street, you should:
questions.answerA: Signal your intention to turn for at least 100 feet.
questions.answerB: Look out the right side of the windshield for pedestrians.
questions.answerC: Get into right lane well ahead of the turn.
questions.explanation: When you plan to turn from a two-way street onto another two-way street, get into the right lane and signal well in advance. Watch for pedestrians who are crossing the intersection by looking out the right side of your windshield.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: A series of curves is ahead.
questions.answerC: An S-curve is ahead.
questions.answerD: The road will be slippery when wet.
questions.explanation: This sign warns that especially slippery conditions exist when the road is wet.

questions.question: If you are involved in a serious motor vehicle crash:
questions.answerB: Call the police.
questions.answerC: Determine if anyone is injured.
questions.explanation: If you are involved in a crash, move your vehicle off of the road and stop, if possible. If anyone is injured, call 911 and provide appropriate help. You must report the crash to law enforcement if there is an injury, a death, and/or more than $1,000 in property damage (or more than $200 worth of damage made to non-vehicle government property, such as signs or guardrails).

questions.question: Certain highway signs require drivers to obey an indicated instruction. Such signs are known as:
questions.answerB: Warning signs.
questions.answerC: Information signs.
questions.explanation: Regulatory signs require drivers to obey an indicated instruction. Failure to comply is subject to penalty.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Multiple turns.
questions.answerC: Lane shifting.
questions.explanation: Warning signs prepare drivers for upcoming road conditions and hazards and are usually yellow with black markings. This sign alerts drivers to potential traffic merging from the right. Drivers should prepare to allow the traffic to merge safely.

questions.question: If you drive past your desired destination while in heavy traffic on a city street, you should:
questions.answerB: Back up to where you should have stopped.
questions.answerC: Signal and make a U-turn.
questions.explanation: If you realize you've passed your destination while driving in heavy traffic on a city street, you should circle around the block. Never make a U-turn where it may disrupt traffic.

questions.question: Slow down, yield, and be prepared to stop for pedestrians:
questions.answerA: Only if a traffic light is yellow or red.
questions.answerB: As they are crossing or walking on the roadway.
questions.answerC: Only if they are in marked crosswalks.
questions.answerD: Only if they are crossing the roadway.
questions.explanation: Slow down, yield, and be prepared to stop when approaching pedestrians who are walking on or crossing the roadway. Always yield to pedestrians on the roadway, even if they are not following right-of-way laws.

questions.question: To keep your vehicle from being struck from behind:
questions.answerA: Drive a little faster than surrounding traffic to widen the gap between you and the vehicle behind you.
questions.answerB: Brake harder than usual.
questions.answerC: Keep pace with surrounding traffic.
questions.answerD: Drive more slowly than surrounding traffic to maintain better control of your vehicle.
questions.explanation: It is a good idea to match the pace of surrounding traffic, within the legal speed limit. Driving with the flow of traffic keeps traffic moving and helps prevent rear-end collisions.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about railroad crossings is true?
questions.answerA: It is against the law to go around lowered gates at a crossing.
questions.answerB: You must stop at a railroad crossing when directed to do so by a flagger.
questions.answerC: Not all railroad crossings are equipped with flashing red signals and gates.
questions.explanation: You must stop at a railroad crossing when directed to do so by a flagger, stop sign, or warning devices, such as gates or flashing lights. Not all railroad crossings are equipped with such devices. It is against the law to drive around lowered railroad crossing gates.

questions.question: Distracted drivers are at a greater risk of a crash when they are using which of the following?
questions.answerB: Radio
questions.answerC: Cell phone
questions.explanation: Using a cell phone (including a hands-free phone) or any kind of audio device (including a radio or CD player) can be a dangerous distraction and contributes to the risk of a crash.

questions.question: This sign is a:
questions.answerB: Regulatory sign.
questions.answerC: Warning sign.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually diamond-shaped and yellow with black lettering or symbols. They warn drivers about special situations or potential hazards ahead.

questions.question: Do not pass:
questions.answerB: When school bus lights are flashing.
questions.answerC: When approaching an intersection.
questions.explanation: You should never pass if there is an oncoming vehicle in the passing lane, if your view is blocked by a curve or hill, at an intersection, before or on a railroad crossing or bridge, or in any other no passing zone. Unless you are on the opposite side of a multilane roadway with a median or shared center turn lane, you may not pass a stopped school bus that has its flashing red lights activated.

questions.question: You are driving when your power steering stops working. You should:
questions.answerA: Honk your horn and turn off the ignition.
questions.answerB: Turn on your hazard lights and brace yourself.
questions.answerC: Work hard to steer, reduce your speed, drive to a safe area, and stop.
questions.explanation: If your power steering stops working, additional effort will be required to maintain steering control. Reduce your speed and pull off the roadway to stop in a safe area.

questions.question: When changing lanes, you can check your blind spots by:
questions.answerB: Using the outside rearview mirror.
questions.answerC: Using both inside and outside rearview mirrors.
questions.answerD: Turning your head and looking over your shoulder.
questions.explanation: You should turn your head to check your blind spots before every lane change.

questions.question: After stopping for a school bus that is unloading children:
questions.answerA: Do not proceed until the children wave to you.
questions.answerB: Watch for children walking along the side of the road.
questions.answerC: Accelerate quickly.
questions.explanation: After stopping for a school bus that has its stop arm extended and its lights flashing, watch for children walking along the side of the road. You should always drive with caution when driving near children.

questions.question: When two vehicles arrive to an intersection at the same time, which one has the right-of-way when no signs or signals indicate rules?
questions.answerA: The car approaching from the right has the right-of-way.
questions.answerB: The car approaching from the left has the right-of-way.
questions.answerC: The car in which the driver sounds his horn first has the right-of-way.
questions.answerD: The car that is traveling the fastest has the right-of-way.
questions.explanation: At an intersection of two similar roads without a traffic control device, a driver must yield to a vehicle approaching from the right.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Lane shifting.
questions.answerC: Low clearance.
questions.explanation: Warning signs prepare drivers for upcoming road conditions and hazards and are usually yellow with black markings. This sign tells drivers that they may encounter traffic coming from the opposite direction.
